Statements 1 and 2 are correct: Goods and Services Tax Network (GSTN) is a non-profit non-government company, which will provide shared IT infrastructure and service to both central and state governments including tax payers and other stakeholders. It will also create the composition of a GST council secretariat for the new tax regime.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following  best explains tax expenditure?
(a) The tax revenue lost due to exemptions to the taxpayers.
(b) The money spent on tax collection.
(c) Money spent on tax litigations against tax evaders.
(d) Both (a) and (c)
batch.explanation:
Tax Expenditures, refers to the opportunity cost of taxing at concessional rates, or the opportunity cost of giving exemptions, deductions, rebates, deferrals credits etc. to the taxpayers. It indicates the revenue that could have been collected by the Government if not for such measures.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following best describes a Tax mitigation technique?
(a) Investment in provident fund, pension scheme, health insurance, etc
(b) Under reporting of income during a financial year.
(c) No reporting of income earned from other sources.
(d) Attempt to shift the incidence of tax to others.
batch.explanation:
Tax mitigation is when a taxpayer uses a fiscal incentive (tax concession) available to him in the tax legislation so that he need not pay tax which he has to otherwise. The taxpayer takes advantage of a fiscal incentive in the form of a tax concession.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. Cess is tax on tax earmarked for a particular purpose.
2. Surcharge is a tax on tax imposed solely for the purposes of the union.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Cess may be in the nature of a tax or a fee but it is imposed for a specific purpose, as identified in the charging legislation. Article 270 of the Constitution describes a cess. Cesses may be levied by the union or state governments. Cesses are named after the identified purpose; the purpose itself must be certain and for public good. In the case of a cess which has the attributes of a tax (cess tax), while the taxpayer does not have the right to ask for a reciprocal benefit, the proceeds ought to be spent only for the earmarked purpose. In simple words, a cess tax is an earmarked tax.
Statement 2 is correct: On the other hand, a surcharge is a tax on tax imposed for the purposes of the union. A surcharge is dealt with under Article 271 of the Constitution.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Under which of the following tax systems, the marginal tax rate increases with an increase in taxable income?
(a) Progressive tax system
(b)  Regressive tax system
(c)  Proportional tax system
(d)  Degressive tax system
batch.explanation:
Marginal tax rate increases with increase in taxable income under progressive tax system. In the Regressive tax system marginal tax rate decreases with increase in taxable income. For the Degressive tax system it initially increases with increase in taxable income but then becomes constant.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to Taxation, consider the
following statements:
1. Ad valorem tax is a tax that is imposed on
the value of a good or service.
2. Specific Tax is a Tax which is imposed on
quantity sold.
Which of the statements given above is are
correct:
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Ad Valorem Tax is a Tax which is imposed on the total value of a commodity. The Latin phrase ad valorem means “according to value.” All ad valorem taxes are levied based on the determined value of the item being taxed. In the most common application of ad valorem taxes, which are municipal property taxes, the real estate of property owners is periodically assessed by a public tax assessor to determine its current value. 
Statement 2 is correct: A specific tax is a fixed amount of tax placed on a particular good. It is also referred to as a per-unit tax, and the tax will depend on the quantity.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to surcharge and Cess,
Consider the following statements:
1. Surcharge imposed by the central
government is a tax levied by the
government for a specific purpose.
2. Cess is levied on the payable tax in a
progressive way.
Select the correct answer using the code given
below:
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
• Cess imposed by the central government is
a tax levied by the government for a specific
purpose.
• Surcharge is levied on the payable tax.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following activities
1. Restoration of lost cultural heritage.
2. Burning of fossil fuel.
3. Research for new technology.
4. Consumption of cigarette.
How many of the above should be considered as “Pigovian Taxation”?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c)Only Three
(d) All Four
batch.explanation:
A Pigovian tax is a government cost on any activity that creates socially harmful externalities. (An externality is an activity that creates a negative effect on others in a society but not necessarily the person who does that activity). Pigovian taxes shift the costs from society to the producers of these externalities. Example- Gas, carbon, and noise taxes are examples of Pigovian taxes. Restoration of lost cultural heritage and Research for new technology does not create any harmful externalities.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the Laffer curve, which of the following is/are correct?
(a)  It shows the relationship between government tax expenditure and tax revenue.
(b) It shows the relationship between tax rates and the amount of tax revenue collected by governments..
(c)  It suggests that tax revenue and tax rates are directly proportional.
(d)  It shows the relationship between number of taxpayers and non-taxpayers.
batch.explanation:
Invented by Arthur Laffer, the Laffer curve shows the relationship between tax rates and tax revenue collected by governments. The Laffer Curve suggests that, as taxes increase from low levels, tax revenue collected by the government also increases. It also shows that tax rates increasing after a certain point would cause people not to work as hard or not at all, thereby reducing tax revenue.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1.  Capital receipts of the government create future liabilities.
2.  Revenue expenditure does not create any asset or dilute any existing liability.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Capital receipts are the receipts which create future liabilities as it includes borrowings, dilution of existing assets, sale and disinvestment of assets etc.
Statement 2 is correct: Revenue expenditure is the expenditure which does not create any asset or dilute any existing liability. It includes salary paid, interest payment on past loans etc.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following statements regarding divisible pool in taxation regime.
1. The divisible pool is that portion of gross tax revenue which is distributed between the Centre and the States.
2. The divisible pool consists of all taxes except surcharges and cess levied for specific purpose, net of collection charges.
Which of the statements given above is are
correct:
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
The divisible pool is that portion of gross tax revenue which is distributed between the Center and the States. The divisible pool consists of all taxes, except surcharges and cess levied for specific purposes, net of collection charges. Hence both statements are correct.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following expenditures are considered as ‘Revenue Expenditure’ of the government?
1. Subsidies on public distribution.
2. Interest paid on borrowing and other liabilities.
3. Expenditure on Union Territories without legislature.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 and 3 only
(c) 1 and 2 only
(d) 1, 2 and 3
batch.explanation:
Expenditures incurred to meet day to day and regular needs of government and that will not yield any revenue in future are termed as revenue expenditure. It is a one-way payment. It means, if the government spends money, it cannot recover it. The following three categories are considered under revenue Expenditure. 
Interest Payments: Interest paid on borrowing and other liabilities and discounts on treasury bills constitute this category. 
Subsidies: Subsidies on public distribution, fertilizers, etc. are included under it. 
Expenditure on Union Territories without Legislature: Expenditure towards administration and other expenditure on Union territories without Legislature.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics
batch.sub_topic: Capital and Revenue- Receipts and Expenditure

batch.text:
Which of the following expert committees are related to reforms in Government Expenditure?
1. Bimal Jalan Committee
2. Rangarajan Committee
3. Tendulkar Committee
4. Urjit Patel Committee
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 and 2 only
(b) 1, 2, and 4 only
(c) 2, 3 and 4 only
(d) 1, 3 and 4 only
batch.explanation:
The Government of India appointed certain expert committees on the Government expenditure and its management.These committees highlighted the problems of revenue and capital expenditure.
Bimal Jalan Committee and Rangarajan Committee are few of such committees.
Tendulkar headed a namesake committee, The Suresh Tendulkar Committee, which was responsible for studying the portion of the population that lived below the poverty line (BPL). 
Urjit Patel Committee was set up to give recommendations on revising and strengthening the monetary policy framework. This committee was set up by the former RBI governor Raghuram Rajan.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics
batch.sub_topic: Capital and Revenue- Receipts and Expenditure

batch.text:
Which of the following are non-debt creating capital receipt of the government?
1. Grants recieved.
2. Recovery of Loans.
3. Small savings instruments such as Provident funds.
4. Disinvestment proceeds.
Select the correct answer using code given below:
(a) 1 and 3 only
(b) 2 and 4 only
(c) 1, 2 and 4 only
(d) 1, 2, 3 and 4
batch.explanation:
Debt creating capital receipts of the government includes:
Borrowing by the government from Public, RBI, Commercial banks and other financial institutions foreign governments and international organizations, small savings instruments such as Post-office Savings Accounts etc., and Provident funds. 
Rest others are non-debt creating funds:
• Dividend from Reserve Bank of India
• Recovery of Loans
• Proceeds from the sale of shares of Public Sector Enterprises and disinvestment proceeds.                                                                     Grants recieved forms part of revenue reciepts.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following situations best describes the ‘crowding out’ effect?
(a) A situation when decreasing interest rates lead to decreased government investment.
(b) When there is less funds available for the government to invest in the economy.
(c) When the government uses fiscal policy to kick start growth during a recession.
(d) A situation when increased interest rates lead to a reduction in private investment spending.
batch.explanation:
Sometimes, the government adopts an expansionary fiscal policy stance and increases its spending to boost economic activity. This leads to an increase in interest rates. Increased interest rates affect private investment decisions. A high magnitude of the crowding out effect may even lead to lesser income in the economy.
With higher interest rates, the cost for funds to be invested increases and affects their accessibility to debt financing mechanisms. This leads to lesser investment ultimately and crowds out the impact of the initial rise in the total investment spending. Usually the initial increase in government spending is funded using higher taxes or borrowing on part of the government.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics
batch.sub_topic: Capital and Revenue- Receipts and Expenditure

batch.text:
Which of the following is the direct effect when government borrows to increase spending?
(a) Decrease in private investment.
(b) Decrease in interest rates.
(c) Increase in private consumption.
(d) Decrease in savings.
batch.explanation:
• The crowding out effect is an economic theory that argues that rising public sector spending drives down or even eliminates private sector spending.
• The crowding out effect is a theory that suggests that increased government spending ultimately decreases private sector spending.
• This is due to the higher cost of loans and reduced income that can result when the government increases taxes or borrows by selling Treasuries to obtain more revenue for its own spending.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following statement is not correct about the capital receipts?
(a) Loans from foreign governments and bodies constitute capital receipts
(b) Disinvestment proceeds are part of capital receipts
(c) Recoveries of loans from state governments are constituents of capital receipts
(d) None of the above
batch.explanation:
Capital receipts consist of Loans from foreign governments and bodies, Disinvestment proceeds and Recoveries of loans from state governments. 
Hence, Statement 1,2 and 3 are correct.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics
batch.sub_topic: Capital and Revenue- Receipts and Expenditure

batch.text:
Fiscal consolidation, often in the news, can be achieved by which of the following?
1. Reducing the fiscal deficit.
2. Policies to increase revenue.
3. Direct Benefit Transfer
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 2 and 3 only
(b) 1 only
(c) 1 and 2 only
(d) 1, 2 and 3
batch.explanation:
Fiscal Consolidation refers to the policies undertaken by Governments (national and sub-national levels) to reduce their deficits and accumulation of debt stock. It is a process where the government's fiscal health is improved, indicated by reducing fiscal deficit to levels which are manageable and bearable for the economy. Improved tax revenue realization and better aligned expenditure are thus components of fiscal consolidation.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following actions:
1. reducing taxes
2. getting more loans
3. reducing subsidies
How many of the actions given above can help in fiscal consolidation?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Fiscal consolidation is a reduction in the underlying fiscal deficit. So, by increasing revenues and decreasing expenditure, we can undertake fiscal consolidation. While getting more loans may increase receipts, it will not help in fiscal consolidation as that loan has to be repaid back along with interest. So loans add more to the expenditure than it contributes to receipts. Increasing taxes and reducing subsidies will increase revenues and decrease expenditure respectively contributing to fiscal consolidation.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) review committee, consider the following statements:
1. It has recommended fiscal deficit to zero by March 31, 2020
2. it has recommended setting up an independent Fiscal Council to forecast key macro variables.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct? 
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2 
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: It has recommended a fiscal deficit of 3 percent of GDP by March 31, 2020 . The center should reduce its fiscal deficit to 2.5% by 2023.
Statement 2 is correct: It has recommended setting up an independent Fiscal Council to forecast key macro variables.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following statements with reference to Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act 2003
1. It prohibits government borrowing from the RBI.
2. It requires the central government to limit its debt to 40 percent of GDP by the year 2024-25.
3. The government cannot deviate from the annual fiscal deficit target set under the act.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 only 
(b) 1 and 2 only
(c) 2 and 3 only
(d) 1, 2 and 3
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: The act prohibits borrowing by the government from the RBI and makes it mandatory for the government to reduce fiscal deficits and adhere to a path of fiscal consolidation.                                                                       Statement 2 is correct: It sets a target to limit the debt of the central government to 40 percent of GDP by year 2024-25 and requires the government to limit the fiscal deficit to 3% of the GDP by March 31, 2021.
Statement 3 is not correct: The government can deviate from the framework of fiscal consolidation only in case of natural calamity, national security and other exceptional grounds which the Central Government may specify.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following documents is/are tabled annually before the Parliament along with the annual financial statement?
1. Macroeconomic Framework Statement
2. Medium Term Fiscal Policy Statement
3. Fiscal Policy Strategy Statement
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 and 2 only
(b) 3 only
(c) 2 only
(d) 1, 2 and 3
batch.explanation:
The Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management Act 2003 has mandated that three documents be tabled annually before the Parliament along with the annual financial statement(budget). The three documents are: 
1. Macroeconomic Framework Statement, 
2. Medium Term Fiscal Policy Statement, 
3. Fiscal Policy Strategy Statement.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following statements regarding Gender based budgeting.
1. The central government introduced gender budgeting in 2015-16 as a budgetary practice.
2. The objective of gender budgeting was to ensure that policy commitments and financial outlays are made on a gender perspective
Which of the statements given above is/are incorrect? 
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Gender budgeting is an approach designed to mainstream the gender dimension into all stages of the budget cycle. It refers to the process of conceiving, planning, approving, executing, monitoring, analyzing and auditing budgets in a gender-sensitive way. 
Statement 1 is not correct: The central government introduced gender budgeting in 2005-06 as a budgetary practice. The GBS captures the total quantum of resources earmarked for women in a financial year.
Statement 2 is correct: Objective of gender budgeting was to ensure that policy commitments and financial outlays are made on a gender perspective.
Additional Information: 
Gender budgeting in India follows the following measures in accounting gender specific programmes.
i. Specifically targeted expenditure to women and girls;
ii. Pro-women allocations, which are the composite expenditure schemes with a significant women’s component; and
iii. Residual public expenditures that have gender–differential impacts.
A separate gender budget statement is also attached as part of the general budget. The budget 2016-17 has a separate gender budget under statement No. 20, mentioned under Expenditure statement.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following are part of the Consolidated Fund of India?
1. Income Tax Receipts
2. Proceeds of National Savings Certificate (NSC)
3. Investments in Provident Fund
4. Loans from the World Bank.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 and 2 only
(b) 2, 3 and 4 only
(c) 1 and 4 only
(d) 1, 3 and 4 only
batch.explanation:
The consolidated fund has been constituted under Article 266 (1) of the Constitution of India. Revenues received by the government and expenses made by it, excluding the exceptional items, are part of the Consolidated Fund. It includes receipts from direct taxes and indirect taxes, money borrowed and receipts from loans given by the government flow into the Consolidated Fund of India. 
Proceeds of National Savings Certificate (NSC) and Investments in Provident Fund are deposited in the Public Account of India.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to different types of budgeting, consider the following statements: 
1. Performance budgeting presents government operations in terms of functions, programmes, activities and projects.
2. Zero Based Budgeting requires program activities and services be justified annually during the budget development process.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct? 
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Performance budgeting presents government operations in terms of functions, programmes, activities and projects. The performance-based budgeting process is a tool that program administrators can use to manage more cost-efficient and effective budgeting outlays. 
Statement 2 is correct: The basic tenet of zero based budgeting (ZBB) is that program activities and services must be justified annually during the budget development process. Developed by Peter Pyhrr in the 1970s, the organization's needs and costs are analyzed by starting from a "zero base" at the beginning of every period.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following.
1.Recovery of Loans
2. Disinvestments receipts
3.Securities against Public Provident Fund
How many of the above is/are part of  Non-Debt Capital Receipt.
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
All Government receipts which either create liability or reduce assets are treated as capital receipts whereas receipts which neither create liability nor reduce assets of Government are called revenue receipts.
Examples of Capital Receipts which create liability are Borrowing and raising of funds from Public Provident Fund and Small savings deposits.
Examples of Capital Receipts which reduce assets are Disinvestment and Recovery of Loans.
Non Debt Capital Receipts consists of Recovery of Loans and Disinvestment Proceeds as government is not bound to pay back and there is no liability.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following statements with respect to Current Account Deficit (CAD):
1. Current Account records the net change of assets and liabilities during the given year.
2. A current account deficit indicates that a country is importing more than it is exporting.
3. India’s current account deficit is constantly declining in the last decade.
How many of the statement(s) given above is/are not correct?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: The current account can be expressed as the difference between the value of exports of goods and services and the value of imports of goods and services.
Statement 2 is correct: A deficit then means that the country is importing more goods and services than it is exporting.
Statement 3 is not correct: India’s current account deficit is not constantly declining in the last decade.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following statements regarding Primary Deficit;
1. Primary deficit indicates the amount of borrowing which the government needs excluding the interest component.
2. Primary deficit can be calculated by deducting interest payments of the borrowings from the current year’s fiscal
deficit.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct:
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is Correct: Primary deficit indicates the amount of borrowing which the government needs excluding the interest component.
Statement 2 is Correct: Primary deficit can be calculated by deducting interest payments of the borrowings from the current year’s fiscal deficit. Fiscal deficit can be calculated by finding the difference between the total income and total expenditure of the government.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following best explains ‘Disinflation’?
(a) Fall in the general level of prices that cause fall in employment too.
(b) Fall in the general level of prices but without causing unemployment.
(c) Increase in the level of prices but in an irregular manner.
(d) Decrease in the rate of inflation.
batch.explanation:
Disinflation is a decrease in the rate of inflation. Although sometimes confused with deflation, disinflation is not considered as problematic because prices do not actually drop, and disinflation does not usually signal the onset of a slowing economy. Deflation is represented as a negative growth rate, such as -0.5%, while disinflation is shown as a change in the inflation rate from 4% one year to 3% the next. Disinflation does not reveal any information about the trends of employment.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the economic condition of a country, who among the following is/are likely to be benefited by inflation?
1. Creditors
2. Debtors
3. Bond-holders
 Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) 1 and 3 only
(d) 2 and 3 only
batch.explanation:
Option 1 is not correct: When prices rise, the value of money falls. Although the creditors get back the same amount of money which they lent, they receive less in real terms because the value of money falls. 
Option 2 is correct: Though debtors return the same amount of money, they pay less in terms of goods and services. This is because the value of money is less than when they borrowed the money. Thus the burden of the debt is reduced and debtors gain.
Option 3 is not correct: Bond-holders are essentially creditors who lose in the event of inflation as they receive a lesser amount of capital in real terms because the value of money falls.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. Wholesale Price Index (WPI) captures the price changes of goods and services at the point of bulk transactions.
2. Producer Price Index (PPI) is currently used in India to determine the average change in prices received by the producer.
3. Weights of items in Consumer Price Index (CPI) is derived from Consumer Expenditure Surveys. 
 Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 and 3 only
(b) 2 only
(c) 1 and 2 only
(d) 3 only
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: Wholesale Price Index (WPI) captures the price changes of goods at the point of bulk transactions amounting to 2/3rd of India’s economic activity. It doesn’t take the value of services into account. 
Statement 2 is not correct: Producer Price Index (PPI) is not being currently used in India. In May, 2018 the government proposed to come out with a Producers Price Index (PPI) next month for 10 services including telecom and railways on an experimental basis.
Statement 3 is correct: Consumer Price Index (CPI) measures the change in average prices that a consumer pays. The prices received by the producers differ from the prices paid by the consumers on account of various factors such as taxes, trade and transport margin, distribution cost etc. Weights of items in CPI are derived from Consumer Expenditure Surveys whereas for PPI it is calculated on the basis of Supply Use tables.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the Phillips curve, which of the following is/are correct?
(a) It shows the relationship between government tax expenditure and tax revenue.
(b) It states that inflation and unemployment have a stable and directly proportional relationship
(c)  It suggests that tax revenue and tax rates are directly proportional.
(d)  It states that inflation and unemployment have a stable and inverse relationship.
batch.explanation:
The Phillips curve is an economic concept developed by A. W. Phillips stating that inflation and unemployment have a stable and inverse relationship. The theory claims that with economic growth comes inflation, which in turn should lead to more jobs and less unemployment.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Under which of the following conditions is stagflation likely to occur?
(a) High inflation, low unemployment, stagnant economic growth.
(b) High inflation, high unemployment, stagnant economic growth.
(c) Low inflation, high economic growth.
(d) Low inflation, Low economic growth.
batch.explanation:
The word ‘Stagflation’ is made up of two words, i.e., stagnation and inflation. Under this type of inflation, though the economic growth stagnates, it still has a higher level of inflation and unemployment.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following does not belong to the group of the other three?
(a) Proportional Money
(b) Reserve Tranche Position
(c) Minimum Reserve System
(d) Fractional Reserve System
batch.explanation:
A country's Reserve Tranche Position is the difference between the International Monetary Fund's holdings of that country's currency and the country's IMF-designated quota. Rest others are systems regulating printing of money by Central Banks.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics
batch.topic: International Institutions- IMF and World bank

batch.text:
Which of the following is not a part of the World Bank Group?
(a) The International Development Association (IDA)
(b) The International Trade Center (ITC)
(c) The Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA)
(d) The International Center for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID)
batch.explanation:
All except the International Trade Center (ITC) are part of the World Bank Group.
The World Bank Group consists of:
1.International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD)
2.International Finance Corporation (IFC)
3.International Development Association (IDA)
4.International Centre for Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID), 
5.Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA).
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics
batch.topic: International Institutions- IMF and World bank

batch.text:
The Washington Consensus, sometimes mentioned in the news, is related with 
(a) human rights principles.
(b) liberalization of economies.
(c) consular access to foreign nationals.
(d) rights of children.
batch.explanation:
Washington Consensus is a set of neoliberal economic prescriptions made by the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank, and the U.S. Treasury to developing countries that faced economic crises. It recommended structural reforms that increased the role of market forces in exchange for immediate financial help. The term was coined by British economist John Williamson in 1989.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics
batch.topic: International Institutions- IMF and World bank

batch.text:
With reference to the bond market in India, consider the following statements:
1. The price of a bond is directly proportional to the market rate of interest.
2. If the price of a bond rises above its present value, it becomes less attractive to people.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: The price of a bond is inversely related to the market rate. As the market rate increases, the present value of bonds decreases. The present value of a bond is calculated by simply discounting all the return obtained from the bond over its lifetime using the prevailing market interest rate. As interest rate increases the discounted present value decreases.
Statement 2 is correct: Competitive bidding will raise the price of the bond above its face value, till the price of the bond is equal to its Present Value (PV). If the price rises above the PV the bond becomes less attractive and people would like to get rid of it. The bond will be in excess supply and there will be downward pressure on the bond price which will bring it back to the PV.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to Masala Bonds, consider the following statements:
1.  These are rupee-denominated bonds issued outside India.
2.  The bonds are underwritten by the Reserve Bank of India.
3.  Both the Government and Private entities can issue these bonds.
How many of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a)  Only One
(b)  Only Two
(c)  All Three
(d)  None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 and 3 correct: Masala bonds are rupee denominated bonds, issued by an Indian entity in foreign markets to raise money, in Indian currency. Both the Government and Private entities can issue these bonds.
Statement 2 is not correct: Any corporate or body corporate is eligible to issue Rupee denominated bonds. RBI has allowed Indian banks to issue masala bonds. Banks can participate as arrangers, underwriters, market makers and traders in rupee-denominated bonds issued overseas.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
If RBI allows retail investors to open Gilt accounts with it, it will
(a)  Allow retail investors to invest directly in the foreign stocks through an RBI managed account.
(b)  Allow retail investors to directly invest in Government Securities.
(c)  Create opportunities for retail investors to virtually participate in underwriting of IPOs.
(d)  Open foreign exchange markets for retail investors.
batch.explanation:
A “Gilt Account” means an account opened and maintained for holding Government securities, by an entity or a person including a person resident outside India with a Custodian permitted by the Reserve Bank of India to open and maintain Constituent Subsidiary General Ledger Account with the Public Debt Office of the Reserve Bank of India. Thus, If RBI allows retail investors to open Gilt accounts with it, it will allow retail investors to directly invest in Government Securities.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to ‘Exchange Traded Funds’ (ETFs), consider the following statements:
1. They are listed and traded on exchanges like stocks.
2. ETFs do not offer intraday purchase and sale on the Exchange.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
An ETF is a basket of stocks that reflects the composition of an Index, like S&P, CNX, Nifty or BSE Sensex. The ETFs trading value is based on the net asset value of the underlying stocks that it represents.
Statement 1 is correct: Exchange Traded Funds are essentially Index Funds that are listed and traded on exchanges like stocks. 
Statement 2 is not correct: They provide liquidity for investors with a shorter-term horizon as they can trade intra-day and can have quotes near NAV during the course of trading day.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following statements about Participatory Notes
1. They are issued by Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI).
2. They are Off-shore Derivatives Investments (ODI)
3. The holders of P-Notes need to regularly report their investment to Regulators in India.
How many of the following is/are correct about Participatory Notes (P-Notes)?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: Participatory Notes (P-Notes) are financial instruments issued by a registered foreign institutional investor (FII) to an overseas investor who wishes to invest in Indian stock markets without registering themselves with Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) (the market regulator). 
Statement 2 is correct: P-Notes are Offshore Derivative Investments (ODIs) with equity shares or debt securities as underlying assets.
Statement 3 is not correct: While the FIIs have to report all such investments each quarter to SEBI, holders of P-Notes need not disclose their identity. Lack of such reporting and anonymity makes P-Notes worrying.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to difference between IPO and FPO, consider the following statements:
1. While IPO is the first issue of shares after listing of a company, FPO is a term for subsequent issues after IPO.
2. FPO seeks to open up ownership of shares in the company to the public whereas IPO is used to diversify public ownership.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: Through an Initial Public Offering, previously unlisted companies can go public and issue shares through subscription. IPO is the first step before shares of a company are officially listed for trading on stock exchanges.
A Follow-on Public Offering (FPO) is a sale of shares by a publicly traded company for the second or third time or consecutive time.
Statement 2 is not correct: Difference between an IPO and FPO may also have to do with whether the fresh capital raised is used for expansion or dilution of promoters’ stake. The objective of an IPO is capital infusion by way of opening up ownership of shares in the company to the public. Companies can either raise funds by borrowing and increasing debt on their books or by selling ownership stake through an IPO. After an IPO, as the company grows, it may need more funds for expansion and be rightly in the position to dilute ownership further. That’s when an FPO is issued. The objective of an FPO is to diversify public ownership. FPO may also be issued to dilute the shareholding of the promoters.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following:
1.  A future contract in the stock market allows an investor to speculate on the direction of a security, commodity, or a financial instrument.
2.  A stock option makes it obligatory for an investor to buy or sell a stock at an agreed upon price and date.
3.  A Swap refers to an exchange of one financial instrument for another between the parties concerned.
How many of the above given statements is/are correct?
(a)  Only One
(b)  Only Two
(c)  All Three
(d)  None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Futures are financial contracts obligating the buyer to purchase an asset or the seller to sell an asset and have a predetermined future date and price. A futures contract allows an investor to speculate on the direction of a security, commodity, or a financial instrument.
Statement 2 is not correct: A stock option gives an investor the right, but not the obligation, to buy or sell a stock at an agreed upon price and date. There are two types of options: puts, which is a bet that a stock will fall, or calls, which is a bet that a stock will rise.
Statement 3 is correct: A swap is a derivative contract through which two parties exchange the cash flows or liabilities from two different financial instruments. The most common kind of swap is an interest rate swap. Swaps do not trade on exchanges, and retail investors do not generally engage in swaps.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
These are debt instruments issued by the Government of India and acknowledge the Government’s debt obligation. They have zero coupon security and pay no interest. Instead, they are issued at a discount and redeemed at the face value at maturity. At present they are issued with a maximum tenure of 364 days. 
The above paragraph best describes which of the following debt instruments?
(a) Cash Management Bills (CMBs)
(b) Dated Government Securities
(c) Commercial Paper
(d) Treasury Bills (T-bills)
batch.explanation:
Treasury bills or T-bills are money market instruments, are short term debt instruments issued by the Government of India and are presently issued in three tenors, namely, 91 day, 182 day and 364 day. Treasury bills are zero coupon securities and pay no interest. Instead, they are issued at a discount and redeemed at the face value at maturity.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the ‘Treasury Bills’, consider the following statements:
1. These are issued when the government needs money for a longer period.
2. These are zero coupon securities and pay no interest.
3. These are categorized as money market instruments.
How many of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: When the government is going to the financial market to raise money, it can do it by issuing two types of debt instruments – treasury bills and government bonds. Treasury bills are issued when the government needs money for a shorter period while bonds are issued when it needs debt for more than say five years. Treasury bills, generally shortened as T-bills, have a maximum maturity of 364 days. 
Statement 2 is correct: Treasury bills are presently issued in three maturities, namely, 91 day, 182 day and 364 day. Treasury bills are zero coupon securities and pay no interest. Rather, they are issued at a discount (at a reduced amount) and redeemed (given back money) at the face value at maturity. 
Statement 3 is correct: Money market instruments deal with funds with a maturity of less than one year. As treasury bills have a maximum maturity of 364 days, they are categorized as money market instruments.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
The terms ‘Additional Surveillance Measures (ASM)’ and ‘Graded Surveillance Measure (GSM)’, recently seen in the news, are concerned with the working of How many of the above organizations?
(a)  Reserve Bank of India.
(b)  Securities and Exchange Board of India.
(c)  National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development.
(d)  Pension Fund Regulatory and Development Authority.
batch.explanation:
The terms “Additional Surveillance Measures (ASM)” and “Graded Surveillance Measure (GSM)” in news recently are concerned with the functioning of Securities and Exchange Board of India.
Additional Surveillance Measures (ASM): 
In continuation to various surveillance measures already implemented, SEBI and Exchanges, pursuant to discussions in joint surveillance meetings, have decided that along with the other measures there shall be Additional Surveillance Measures (ASM) on securities with surveillance concerns based on objective parameters viz. Price variation, Volatility etc. In view thereof, shortlisting of securities for placing in ASM is based on an objective criteria covering following parameters and shall be reviewed on bimonthly basis for the applicability of ASM:
High Low Variation
Client Concentration
No. of Price Band Hits
Close to Close Price Variation
PE Ratio
Market Capitalisation
Graded Surveillance Measure (GSM):
Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) and Exchanges in order to enhance market integrity and safeguard interest of investors, have introduced Graded Surveillance Measures (GSM) wherein certain identified securities shall be subjected to enhanced monitoring and surveillance actions.
The main objective of these measures is to:
• Alert and advise investors to be extra cautious while dealing in these securities.
• Advice market participants to carry out necessary due diligence while dealing in these securities
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
National Financial Reporting Authority was established for 
(a) Ensuring improvement in India’s Ranking in World Bank’s Ease of Doing Business Index.
(b) Ensuring compliance of registered corporations with the government's financial policies.
(c) Overseeing and regulating the auditing profession.
(d) All of the above
batch.explanation:
NFRA Recommends accounting and auditing policies and standards to be adopted by companies for approval by the Central Government. It also monitors and enforces compliance with accounting standards and auditing standards.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
If interest rate increases, then the speculative demand for money
(a) decreases.
(b) increases then decreases
(c) remains constant.
(d) increases.
batch.explanation:
Speculative demand for money refers to the desire of the holder to keep the cash balance as an alternative to financial assets like bonds. Under a speculative motive, it is presumed that people can hold their wealth either in the form of bonds or in the form of cash balances. The decisions regarding holding bonds or cash balances depend upon the expectations about changes in the rate of interest or capital value of assets (bonds) in future.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following actions.
1. Increase in Cash Reserve Ratio.
2. Increase in Bank rate.
3. Reduction in Repo rate.
4. Reduction in Statutory Liquidity Ratio.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     How many of the above actions will increase the money supply in an economy?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) Only Three
(d) All Four
batch.explanation:
Option 1 is not correct: When the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) increases the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR), less funds are available with banks as they have to keep larger portions of their cash in hand with RBI.
Option 2 is not correct: Bank rate is the rate charged by the central bank for lending funds to commercial banks. If the bank rate is increased, the commercial banks will borrow less funds and give less loans. This will increase the interest rates as well. And in general, the supply of money in the market will actually decrease.
Option 3 is correct: Repo rate refers to the rate at which commercial banks borrow money by selling their securities to the Central Bank of our country i.e. Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to maintain liquidity. A decline in the repo rate can lead to the banks bringing down their lending rate thus increasing money supply. 
Option 4 is correct: As SLR is decreased banks will have to keep less liquidity with themselves. So more funds will be available to the banks for credit creation (granting loan). The total money supplied in the economy will increase.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the ‘Open Market Operations’, consider the following statements:
1. The operation involves simultaneous purchase and sale of corporate securities to regulate money supply.
2. Adjustment of Cash Reserve Ratio is part of the OMP.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: Open market operations are conducted by the RBI by way of sale or purchase of government securities (G-secs) and not corporate securities to adjust money supply conditions. The central bank sells G-secs to suck out liquidity from the system and buys back G-secs to infuse liquidity into the system.
Statement 2 is not correct: Cash Reserve Ratio is the percentage of deposits which commercial banks are required to keep as cash according to the directions of the central bank. These are not included in the open market operations. Adjustment of CRR is part of quantitative measures taken by RBI to regulate money supply.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the Quantitative tools of credit control, consider the following statements:
1. The bank rate is the maximum rate at which the central bank lends money and rediscounts first-class bills of exchange and securities held by commercial banks.
2. The Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) refers to the share of Net Demand and Time Liabilities that banks have to hold as balances with the RBI.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: The bank rate is the minimum rate at which the central bank lends money and rediscounts first-class bills of exchange and securities held by commercial banks.
Statement 2 is correct: The Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) refers to the share of Net Demand and Time Liabilities that banks have to hold as balances with the RBI.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following mechsnism.
1. Dated Government Securities (G-Secs)
2. Marginal Standing Facility(MSF)
3. Market Stabilisation Scheme(MSS)
4. Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF)
How many of the above are instruments of Monetary Policy in India to control inflation?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) Only Three
(d) All Four
batch.explanation:
Monetary policy is the macroeconomic policy laid down by the central bank. It involves management of money supply and interest rate and is the demand side economic policy used by the government of a country to achieve macroeconomic objectives like inflation, consumption, growth and liquidity. There are various direct and indirect instruments used for implementing monetary policy viz. Repo rate, Reverse Repo rate, Marginal Standing Facility(MSF), Market Stabilisation Scheme(MSS), Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF), Cash Reserve Ratio(CRR), Open Market Operations(OMO).
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following conditions.
1. The current interest rates are low.
2. Savings rates are high. 
3. Monetary policy becomes ineffective.
How many of the above are conditions will lead to Liquidity Trap
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: The liquidity trap is the situation in which the current interest rates are low.
Statement 2 is correct: In the situation of liquidity traps, savings rates are high.
Statement 3 is correct: As part of the liquidity trap, consumers continue to hold funds in standard deposit accounts, such as savings and checking accounts, instead of in other investment options, even when the central banking system attempts to stimulate the economy through the injection of additional funds. These consumer actions, often spurred by the belief of a negative economic event on the horizon, cause monetary policy to be generally ineffective.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following tools. 
1.  Selective credit control
2.  Bank rate policy
3.  Moral suasion
How many of the above tools are quantitative measures of monetary policy?
(a)  Only One
(b)  Only Two
(c)  All Three
(d)  None
batch.explanation:
The quantitative measures regulates the total amount of credit created by the commercial banks. It includes:
Bank Rate
1.Liquid Adjustment Facility (LAF)
Marginal Standing Facility (MSF)
Reserve Requirements
Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR)
Open Market Operations (OMO)
Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR)
Market Stabilization Scheme (MSS)
The qualitative tools of monetary policy are Rationing of credit, Consumer Credit Regulation, Guidelines, Margin requirements, Moral Suasion.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics
batch.sub_topic: Quantitative & Qualitative Tools of Monetary Policy

batch.text:
Consider the following statements 
1. To enable the Central Bank to control the amount of advances the banks can create.
2. To make the people’s deposits with banks safe and liquid.
3. To ensure that the banks have sufficient cash to meet their day-to-day requirements.
In context of the Indian economy,how many of the above is/are the objectives of ‘Statutory Liquidity Ratio’ (SLR) ?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Statutory Liquidity Ratio is the amount of money that is invested in certain specified securities predominantly in Union Government and State Government securities. It is the amount of money which remains blocked for statutory reasons and is not available for investment in various other high earning avenues like loans or other bonds. 
Statement 2 is correct: SLR is predominantly used for investment in government securities, which are backed by the government and hence carry very low risk. This ensures that people’s deposits with banks are safe and liquid.
Statement 3 is not correct: SLR essentially locks the capital of banks and therefore it cannot be used for meeting their day-to-day capital requirements.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Hawkish monetary policy is used by the RBI to address which of the following issues?
1.  Control inflation in the country.
2.  Reduce money supply in the economy.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
The RBI uses the Hawkish/ Stringent monetary policy to control the inflation in the economy/country by pulling money out of circulation from the economy. The hawkish monetary policy has nothing to do with foreign exchange rate and employment generation.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the term ‘Narrow Money’ in India
1. Currency held by the public.
2. Net demand deposits held by commercial banks.
3. Total deposits with Post Office savings.
How many of the above is/are its constituents?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
M1 = CU + DD 
M2 = M1 + Savings deposits with Post Office savings banks
M3 = M1 + Net time deposits of commercial banks.
M4 = M3 + Total deposits with Post Office savings organisations (excluding National Savings 
Certificates) where, CU is currency (notes plus coins) held by the public and DD is net demand 
deposits held by commercial banks. The word ‘net’ implies that only deposits of the public held by the banks are to be included in money supply. 
The interbank deposits, which a commercial bank holds in other commercial banks, are not to be regarded as part of money supply. 
M1 and M2 are known as narrow money. M3 and M4 are known as broad money.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the ‘Money Multiplier’ in an economy, consider the following statements:
1. It is the ratio of the money supply to the stock of high powered money in an economy.
2. A low bank rate increases the value of the money multiplier.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Money multipliers can be defined as the ratio of the stock of money to the stock of high powered money in an economy.
Statement 2 is correct: Banks use a greater (or smaller) proportion of their resources for giving out loans to borrowers or investors, thereby enhancing (or depressing) the multiplier process via assisting (or resisting) secondary money creation. As a result, a low (or high) bank rate increases (or decreases) the value of the money multiplier.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following best describes the term ‘Near Money’?
(a)  A money that possesses intrinsic value on its own.
(b)  A demand deposit with a commercial bank which is withdrawn by cheques.
(c)  A currency note issued by the government of a country.
(d)  A digital currency that can be used to buy goods and services.
batch.explanation:
Credit money or Bank money was used due to the development of banking institutions and their credit creation activities. The term ‘credit money’ refers to the demand deposits of the commercial banks. Demand deposits of the banks are withdrawable through cheques. It serves as money and the cheques are accepted as a means of payments. A cheque by itself is not money; it is only a credit instrument which is used and accepted as a medium of exchange. Therefore, Credit money is regarded as near money.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to Fiat Money, consider the following statements:
1. Only currency notes and not coins constitute fiat money.
2. It possesses intrinsic value.
3. It can not be refused by any citizen for settlement of any kind of transaction.
How many of the above statements is/are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: Both Currency notes and coins constitute fiat money.
Statement 2 is not correct: Fiat Money does not have intrinsic value like a gold or silver coin.
Statement 3 is correct: It cannot be refused by any citizen of the country for settlement of any kind of transaction as it is a legal tender. Cheques drawn on savings or current accounts, however, can be refused by anyone as a mode of payment. Demand deposits are not legal tenders.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to Monetary Policy Committee (MPC),Consider the following statements:
1. It has been constituted under the RBI Act, 1934.
2.The primary objective of MPC is maintaining price stability.
3.The RBI Deputy Governor in charge of monetary policy is one of the members of the committee.
How many of the above mentioned statements is/are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct:The Finance Act 2016 amended the RBI Act 1934 for setting up of a Monetary Policy Committee (MPC).The idea to set up a monetary policy committee was mooted by an RBI-appointed committee led by the then Deputy Governor Urjit Patel.                                                                                                                                                                      Statement 2 is correct:The primary objective of the committee is maintaining price stability while keeping in mind the objective of growth.
Statement 3 is correct: The committee has six members: 
(a) RBI Governor (Chairperson), 
(b) RBI Deputy Governor in charge of monetary policy, 
(c) one official nominated by the RBI Board 
(d) three members appointed by the Central Government based on the recommendations of a search cum selection committee, comprising of the Cabinet Secretary, the 
Secretary of the Department of Economic Affairs, the RBI Governor and three experts in the field of economics or banking as nominated by the central government.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the Public Debt Management Agency (PDMA), how many of the following statements is/are correct?
1. PDMA can establish offices either in India or abroad.
2. The Union Government is empowered to issue directions on Policy to PDMA and the latter is bound by that.
3. It works under the supervision of The Reserve Bank of India.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Public Debt Management Agency (PDMA) is a specialized independent agency that manages the internal and external liabilities of the Central Government in a holistic manner and advises on such matters. PDMA is the Investment Banker or Merchant Banker to the Government. PDMA can establish offices either in India or abroad.
Statement 2 is correct: Being an agency of the Government, the Union Government has the right to terminate the services of a Member of the Board even before the expiry of her tenure on grounds of moral turpitude, unsound mind, insolvency and for abuse of position. The Union Government is empowered to issue directions on Policy to PDMA and the latter is bound by that.
Statement 3 is not correct: The debt management functions comprised of formulation of a calendar for primary issuance, deciding the desired maturity profile of the debt, size and timing of issuance, designing the instruments and methods of raising resources, etc. taking into account government’s needs, market conditions, and preferences of various segments while ensuring that the entire strategy is consistent with the overall macroeconomic policy objectives. All these functions were to be transferred to PDMA in respect of the central government. RBI was required by law to provide all necessary information and assistance to the effective functioning of PDMA. PDMA is an independent agency and doesn’t work under RBI.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the velocity of money, which of the above is correct?
(a) It is the total liability of the monetary authority of the country.
(b) It is the total money in circulation in the country.
(c) It is the rate at which money is exchanged from one transaction to another.
(d) It is the total demand deposits of the commercial banks.
batch.explanation:
The rate at which money is exchanged from one transaction to another, and how much a unit of currency is used in a given period of time. Velocity of money is usually measured as a ratio of GDP to a country’s total supply of money. Velocity is important for measuring the rate at which money in circulation is used for purchasing goods and services. This helps investors gauge how robust the economy is, and is a key input in the determination of an economy’s inflation calculation. Economies that exhibit a higher velocity of money relative to others tend to be further along in the business cycle and should have a higher rate of inflation, all things held constant.
Velocity of Money = GDP / Money Supply
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to Measures of Monetary and Liquidity Aggregates in India, consider the following statements:
1. M1 refers to Currency with the public plus demand deposits with the banking system plus other deposits with the RBI.
2. M2 refers to M1 plus savings deposits of post office savings banks.
3. M3 refers to M2 plus time deposits with the banking system.
How many of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: M1 = Currency with the public + Demand deposits with the banking system + ‘Other’ deposits with the RBI.
Statement 2 is correct: M2 = M1 + Savings deposits of post office savings banks.
Statement 3 is not correct: M3 = M1+ Time deposits with the banking system = Net bank credit to the Government + Bank credit to the commercial sector + Net foreign exchange assets of the banking sector + Government’s currency liabilities to the public – Net nonmonetary liabilities of the banking sector.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to Fiat Money, consider the following statement:
1. Fiat Money is legally recognized to settle all debt and payment with in territorial jurisdiction.
2. Fiat Money have intrinsic value.
3.Cheque is a Fiat Money whereas Crypto currency is not a Fiat Money.
How many of these statement/s given above is/are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Fiat money is a government-issued currency that is not backed by a physical commodity, such as gold or silver, but rather by the government that issued it. 
Statement 2 is not correct: Fiat Money does not have intrinsic value, the money used because of government decree to settle all debt and payment within its territory.
Statement 3 is not correct: Most modern paper currencies are fiat currencies, for example U.S. dollar, Indian Rupee, and other major global currencies. Both Cheque and cryptocurrency is not a Fiat money.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following pairs:
 Committees Objective/   Recommendations
1. Uday Kotak –  Corporate Social Responsibility
2. Rajah Chelliah – Tax Reform 
3. Urjit Patel –  Monetary Policy    
How many of the pairs given above are correctly matched?
(a) None of the pairs
(b) Only one pair
(c) Only two pairs
(d) All three pairs
batch.explanation:
Pair 1 is not correctly matched: Uday Kotak Committee was constituted to improve the standards of Corporate Governance of listed companies in India.
Pairs 2 and 3 are correctly matched: Rajah Chelliah Committee was set up for bringing tax reforms in India. Urjit Patel Committee was set up to review and strengthen the monetary policy.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
What does a bad bank mean?
(a) A bank with more than 7.5% non-performing assets (NPAs) of total loans.
(b) A financial entity set up to buy non-performing assets (NPAs) from banks.
(c) A financial entity set up to grant loans to loss making banks.
(d) A bank setup with a primary objective of making profits by selling bad loans of banks.
batch.explanation:
A bad bank is a financial entity set up to buy non-performing assets (NPAs), or bad loans, from banks. The aim of setting up a bad bank is to help ease the burden on banks by taking bad loans off their balance sheets and get them to lend again to customers without constraints.
A bad bank makes a profit in its operations if it manages to sell the loan at a price higher than what it paid to acquire the loan from a commercial bank. However, generating profits is usually not the primary purpose of a bad bank — the objective is to ease the burden on banks.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation is a wholly owned subsidiary of SEBI.
2. Co-operative Banks are not covered by the Deposit Insurance Scheme.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: DICGC is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Reserve Bank of India.
Statement 2 is not correct: Deposit insurance is compulsory for all banks in the country. Therefore, all public sector banks, private sector banks, local area banks, regional rural banks, small finance banks, payments banks, branches of foreign banks functioning in India, all State, Central and Primary cooperative banks (Urban Cooperative Banks) are registered and insured by the DICGC.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics
batch.sub_topic: Challenges & reforms in banking/ Steps taken by Govt to reduce NPA

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. Capital Adequacy Ratio (CAR) aims to help the banks offset any loss incurred if account-holders fail to repay dues.
2. It is decided by the central banks 
3. In India, scheduled commercial banks are required to maintain a CAR of 5%.
How many of the above mentioned statements are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Capital Adequacy Ratio (CAR) is the ratio of a bank’s capital in relation to its risk weighted assets and current liabilities. The reason minimum capital adequacy ratios (CARs) are critical is to make sure that banks have enough cushion to absorb a reasonable amount of losses before they become insolvent and consequently lose depositors’ funds.                                                                                                                                                                                                Statement 2 is correct:It is decided by central banks and bank regulators to prevent commercial banks from taking excess leverage and becoming insolvent in the process. 
Statement 3 is not correct: The Basel III norms stipulated a capital to risk weighted assets of 8%. However, as per RBI norms, Indian scheduled commercial banks are required to maintain a CAR of 9%.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics
batch.sub_topic: Challenges & reforms in banking/ Steps taken by Govt to reduce NPA

batch.text:
Which of the following is not a responsibility of the Reserve Bank of India?
(a) Custodian of foreign exchange 
(b) Control of credit
(c) Banker to the Government
(d) Loan advancement to industrial groups.
batch.explanation:
The Reserve Bank of India performs a number of functions viz. Issuer of Currency, Banker’s Bank, Banker to the Government, Lender of the last resort, Custodian of foreign exchange, controller of credit in the economy. Loan advancement to industrial groups is not a mandate of the RBI.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the ‘Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation’ (DICGC), consider the following statements:
1. All commercial banks are insured by the DICGC.
2. The limit of insurance cover in case of bank failure on deposits is ₹3 lakh.
3. Deposits of Central/State Governments and inter-bank deposits are also insured by DICGC.
How many of the above statements  is/are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.subject: Economics
batch.sub_topic: Challenges & reforms in banking/ Steps taken by Govt to reduce NPA

batch.text:
Consider the following actions.
1. Creation of credit through lending and investment activities.
2. Discounting bills of exchange. 
3. Purchasing and Selling of the Securities.
How many of the above actions is/are performed by a Commercial Bank in India?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
The roles performed by a commercial bank in India includes accepting deposits, providing loans and advances, discounting bills of exchange, Creation of credit through lending and investment activities, purchasing and selling of the securities etc.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following  NBFC in India.
1.  Non-Operative Financial Holding Company.
2.  Infrastructure Finance Company (IFC) 
3.  Account Aggregators.
4.  Mortgage Guarantee Companies
How many of the above are currently categorized as NBFC in India?
(a)  Only One
(b)  Only Two
(c)  Only Three
(d)  All Four
batch.explanation:
RBI has categorized NBFC into multiple types. The table below has the list and their functions in brief Based on liabilities (NBFC-D)-Deposit-taking Non-Banking Financial Company. (NBFC-ND)-Non-Deposit taking Non-Banking Financial Company Additional, NBFC Non-Deposit is sub-categorized into two parts-Systemically Important NBFC-ND
Others NBFC-ND Based on business activity Investment and Credit Company-ICC
NBFC-Infrastructure Finance Company, Mortgage Guarantee Companies                                                                              NBFC- Non-Operative Financial Holding Company, Micro Finance Company                                                                                   NBFC Factor Systemically Important Core Investment Company (CIC-ND-SI) Infrastructure Debt Fund-NBFC                       NBFC Account Aggregator
NBFC -Peer to Peer lending Platforms Housing Finance Companies.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to Non-Banking Financial Company (NBFC) in India, consider the following statements:
1. NBFC cannot accept demand deposits.
2. NBFC cannot issue cheques drawn on itself.
3. Deposit insurance facility of Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation is available to depositors of NBFCs.
How many of these statements given above is/are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 and 2 are correct: NBFCs lend and make investments and hence their activities are akin to that of banks; however, there are a few differences as given below:
NBFC cannot accept demand deposits; NBFCs do not form part of the payment and settlement system and cannot issue cheques drawn on itself.
Statement 3 is not correct: Deposit insurance facility of Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation is not available to depositors of NBFCs, unlike in case of banks.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following.
1.  Currency held by Public.
2.  Govt. Securities.
3.  Deposits of State Governments.
4.  Deposits of Commercial Banks with RBI.
How many of the above are the liabilities of the Reserve Bank of India?
(a)  Only One
(b)  Only Two
(c)  Only Three
(d)  All Four
batch.explanation:
Option 1 is correct: The currency notes used to purchase the assets are now with the bearer, and are a liability to the RBI, because the bearer of the note can turn up at RBI’s doorstep to claim his share of assets stored in the RBI’s vaults.
Option 2 is not correct: The Government securities are the assets for the RBI.
Option 3 is correct: Deposits of State Governments i.e.State Governments maintain accounts with the Reserve Bank to carry out business transactions. State Governments need to maintain minimum 40 crore balances on every Friday. 
Option 4 is correct: Deposits of commercial banks is a liability to RBI and has to be returned on a timely basis.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Consider the following sectors.
1. Renewable Energy
2. Social Infrastructure
3. Export Credit
How many of the above sectors are included under the Priority Sector Lending norms?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Priority Sector means those sectors which the Government of India and Reserve Bank of India consider as important for the development of the basic needs of the country and are to be given priority over other sectors. The banks are mandated to encourage the growth of such sectors with adequate and timely credit. Priority Sector includes the following categories:
(i) Agriculture 
(ii) Micro, Small and Medium Enterprises
(iii) Export Credit
(iv) Education
(v) Housing
(vi) Social Infrastructure
(vii) Renewable Energy
(viii) Others                                                                                                                                                                Therefore option (c) is the correct answer
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following are part of the core industries of the Indian economy?
1. Refinery
2. Coal 
3. Manufacturing
4. Textile
5. Infrastructure 
Select the correct code using the statements given above:
(a) 3 and 4 only
(b) 1 and 2 only
(c) 1, 3, 4 and 5 only
(d) 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5
batch.explanation:
Eight Core Industries are Electricity, steel, refinery products, crude oil, coal, cement, natural gas and fertilizers.These eight industries have a combined share of above 40% in the Index of Industrial Production (IIP).
The eight core sector industries in decreasing order of their weightage: Refinery Products> Electricity> Steel> Coal> Crude Oil> Natural Gas> Cement> Fertilizers.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
The Hybrid Annuity Model (HAM), often seen in the news, is a mix of which of the following?
1. Build Operate and Transfer (BOT) Annuity models
2. Lease-Develop-Operate (LDO) Annuity models
3. Engineering, Procurement and Construction (EPC)
4. Design-Construct-Manage-Finance (DCMF)
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 and 3 only
(b) 2 and 4 only
(c) 2 and 3 only
(d) 3 and 4 only
batch.explanation:
HAM is a hybrid, a mix of the Engineering, Procurement and Construction (EPC) and Build, Operate, Transfer (BOT) Annuity models. The HAM model has been introduced to rejuvenate the Public-Private Partnership (PPP) mode.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
Which of the following is not a component of the Sagarmala Project?
(a) Port Modernization & New Port Development
(b) Coastal Community Development
(c) Incentive for development of Inland Waterways Transport 
(d) Development of port linked Special Economic Zones
batch.explanation:
The concept of Sagarmala was approved by the Union Cabinet on 25th March 2015. As part of the programme, a National Perspective Plan (NPP) for the comprehensive development of India’s 7,500 km coastline, 14,500 km of potentially navigable waterways and maritime sector has been prepared. The Components of Sagarmala Programme are Port Modernization & New Port Development, Port Connectivity Enhancement, Port-linked Industrialization, Coastal Community Development, Coastal Shipping & Inland Waterways Transport. Development of port linked Special Economic Zones is not a component of the Sagarmala Project.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to the National Investment and Infrastructure Fund (NIIF), consider the following statements:
1. It is registered as a Trust, under Indian Trust Act.
2. It may utilize the proceeds of monetized land and other assets of PSUs for infrastructure development
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: NIIF was formed as a category II AIF, as a Trust, under Indian Trust Act on 28 December 2015. NIIF is not a single entity. There can be more than one fund.
Statement 2 is correct: Domestic pension and provident funds and National Small Savings Fund may also provide funds to the NIIF. NIIF may utilize the proceeds of monetized land and other assets of PSUs for infrastructure development. The NIIF will work out these details in consultation with the Ministry of Finance, to match different investors’ preferences.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Economics

batch.text:
With reference to Infrastructure Debt Funds (IDFs), which of the followingstatements is/are correct:
1. It can be sponsored only by commercial banks
2. It acts as a tool for Viability Gap Funding.
3. A trust based IDF is regulated by SEBI
