In a Presidential government, the President enjoys real powers of the administration and he exercises all those powers, which are given to him under the constitution and the law.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Who among the following headed the steering committee in the Constituent Assembly?
(a)  Sardar Patel
(b)  Rajendra Prasad
(c)  Jawaharlal Nehru
(d)  Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
batch.explanation:
The Steering Committee was headed by Rajendra Prasad.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Which of the following  is not a salient feature of the Constitution of India?
(a)  Supremacy of Parliament
(b)  Lengthiest Constitution
(c)  Single Citizenship
(d)  Independent and Integrated Judiciary
batch.explanation:
All options except Supremacy of Parliament are salient features of Indian Constitution. In India, the Constitution is the Supreme. Parliament is the Supreme in Britain.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

 Schedule Subject Matter

Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.

batch.text:
The Preamble of the Constitution of India aims to secure to all its citizens
(a) Fundamental rights to all individuals.
(b) Fundamental duties to citizens of India.
(c) Dignity of the individual and unity and integrity of the nation.
(d) Security of service to Government servants.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
The words “Socialist” and “Secular” were inserted in the Preamble by the:
(a) Fifteenth Amendment 
(b) Thirty-ninth Amendment
(c) Forty-second Amendment
(d) Forty-fourth Amendment.
batch.explanation:
One of the most significant amendments to the Indian Constitution is the 42nd Amendment Act of 1976 . This Act is also known as the “Mini Constitution” because of the large number of revisions it made. The words socialist, secular, and integrity were added to India’s Constitution by this Amendment act in the preamble of the constitution.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
The Preamble to the Constitution of India is based on the 
(a) Instrument of Instructions contained in the Government of India Act, 1935.
(b) Preamble to the US Constitution.
(c) Objectives Resolution by Jawaharlal Nehru.
(d) Declaration of the Rights of man and citizens inspired by the French Revolution.
batch.explanation:
The Preamble to the Indian Constitution is based on the historic “Objectives Resolution” by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru, which was adopted by the Constituent Assembly on 22nd January 1947.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Which of the following is not correct regarding the Preamble to the Constitution of India?
(a) It is based on the objective resolution passed in the Constituent Assembly.
(b) No appeal can be made in the court of law for violation of the Preamble only .
(c)  It can be amended with a simple majority of each House of the Parliament. 
(d) The Government can make a law based on any provision of the Preamble.
batch.explanation:
The Preamble of the Constitution of India is an introductory document which explains about the philosophy and objectives of the Indian Constitution. 
Features of the Preamble:
1. It is a part of the Constitution but not part of the Basic Structure of the Constitution.
2. One can not appeal in the court of law for violation of the Preamble only.
3. Its amendment requires a special majority.
4. Government can make a law based on any provision of the Preamble.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
The word “socialist” inscribed in the preamble to the Indian constitution aims for which of the following ?
(a)  Nationalisation of all means of production.
(b)  Abolition of Private property.
(c)  Redistribution of public and private property.
(d)  Eradication of poverty as well as inequality of opportunity.
batch.explanation:
As per the Supreme Court of India, the purpose of Indian (Democratic) Socialism is to end poverty, ignorance, disease and inequality of opportunity.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance
batch.sub_topic: Values and Aspiration in the Preamble

batch.text:
Which one of the following objectives is not embodied in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
(a) Liberty of thought
(b) Liberty of profession
(c) Liberty of expression
(d) Liberty of belief
batch.explanation:
The text of the Preamble of the Constitution:
WE, THE PEOPLE OF INDIA, having solemnly resolved to constitute India into a SOVEREIGN SOCIALIST
SECULAR DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC and to secure to all its citizens:
JUSTICE, social, economic and political; LIBERTY of thought, expression, belief, faith and worship;
EQUALITY of status and of opportunity;
and to promote among them all FRATERNITY assuring the dignity of the individual and the unity and integrity
of the Nation;
IN OUR CONSTITUENT ASSEMBLY this twenty-sixth day of November, 1949, do HEREBY ADOPT,
ENACT AND GIVE TO OURSELVES THIS CONSTITUTION.
Thus, Preamble to the Constitution of India embodies liberty of thought, expression, belief, faith and worship
but not economic liberty.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the Preamble of the Constitution, consider the following statements:
1. Socialism implies that our Constitution and the Indian state aim at promoting social transformation to end inequalities.
2. India is a republic because the President of India is elected by the people from amongst the people.
3. Sovereignty implies that India is free from any external interference and is a supreme authority internally also.                                                                                                                                   How many of the above statements are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Socialism: It implies that our Constitution and the Indian state aim at promoting social transformation to end all forms of inequalities and particularly social and economic inequalities. 
Statement 2 is correct: Republic: India is a republic because the President of India i.e. the Head of the Indian State, is elected by the people from amongst the people. 
Statement 3 is correct: Sovereignty: India is a Sovereign state which means that it has complete political freedom. It is free from any external interference and is a supreme authority internally also. 
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance
batch.sub_topic: Values and Aspiration in the Preamble

batch.text:
With reference to Democratic political system, consider the following statements:
1. It enhances the dignity of the individual.
2. It improves the quality of decision making.
3. It provides a method to resolve conflicts.
4. It allows room to correct mistakes.
How many of the above statements suggest that Democratic form of governance is superior to other forms?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) Only Three
(d) All Four
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following objectives:
1. Social Justice
2. Liberty of profession
3. Equality of opportunity
4. Unity and integrity of the Nation
How many of the above given objective/s is/ are stated in the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
(a) Only two
(b) Only three
(c) All four
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Preamble of India seeks to secure the citizen
JUSTICE, social, economic and political;
LIBERTY of thought, expression, belief, faith
and worship;
EQUALITY of status and of opportunity; and to
promote among them all
FRATERNITY assuring the dignity of the
individual and the unity and integrity of the
Nation;
Three of the above given objectives are stated in
the Preamble to the Constitution of India.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance
batch.sub_topic: Values and Aspiration in the Preamble

batch.text:
In which of the following landmark cases the Supreme Court held that Preamble is an integral part of the Indian Constitution?
(a) The Berubari Union case
(b) Waman rao case.
(c) Kesavananda Bharati vs State of Kerala
(d) Maneka Gandhi vs Union of India
batch.explanation:
The Supreme Court of India in the Kesavananda Bharati Case held that the Preamble of the Constitution will now be considered as part of the Constitution overturning its earlier judgment in the Berubari Union case vs Unknown.
Therefore option (c) is correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to “The Rule of Law in India”, consider the following statements
1. It has been incorporated from the Constitution of France. 
2. Equality before the law is a component of the Rule of Law. 
3. It ensures absence of arbitrary power
How many of the above statements is/are correct? 
(a) Only one 
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect:The ‘Rule of Law’ concept has been incorporated in the Indian Constitution from England. 
Statement 2 is correct.:Equality before the law is one of the main principles of Rule of Law. 
Statement 3 is correct.Supremacy of Law, another main principle of Rule of Law, ensures absence of arbitrary power.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following features
1. Independence of the Judiciary
2. Single Citizenship
3. Parliamentary system of Government
4. Largest written Constitution.
5. Adult Universal Franchise
How many of the above given features are
features of Indian Constitution?
(a) Only two
(b) Only three
(c) Only four
(d) All five
batch.explanation:
Some of the salient features or integral parts of Indian Constitution as it stands today are: 
• Lengthiest Written Constitution 
• Drawn from Various Sources 
• Federal System with Unitary Bias
• Parliamentary Form of Government
• Integrated and Independent Judiciary 
• Fundamental Rights 
• Universal Adult Franchise 
• Single Citizenship etc. 
Hence, All five of the above given features are integral part of Indian Constitution.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. Constitutionalism is a doctrine that limits the powers of State
2. Being a democratic country, in India, the laws made by the parliament are supreme. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Constitutionalism is defined as a political theory which limits the powers of state and checks that the laws made by the state are not exercised without any limits. 
Statement 2 is not correct: India has constitutional supremacy and the laws which violate the constitution are deemed as null and void. 
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following.
1. Religion
2. Sex
3. Place of birth
4. Place of residence
On how many of the above grounds, the State is prohibited to discriminate between citizens Under the Fundamental Right of Equality (Article 15) ?

(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) Only Three
(d) All Four
batch.explanation:
Article 15-clause (1) --- the State is prohibited to discriminate between citizens on grounds only of religion, race,sex, caste, place of birth or any of them.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
According to Article 12 of the Constitution of India the term ‘State’ includes how many of the following?
1. Parliament of India
2. Municipal Corporation of Delhi
3. The Board of Control for Cricket in India
Select the correct answer using the codes given below:
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Article 12 of the Indian Constitution defines the term ‘State’, which includes:
•  Government and Parliament of India.
•  Government and Legislatures of states.
•  All local authorities e.g. municipalities, panchayats etc.
•  All other statutory or non-statutory authorities like LIC, ONGC etc.
The Board of Control for Cricket in India is not considered a ‘State’ under Article 12.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to Ordinary Rights and Fundamental Rights, consider the following statements:
1. Unlike ordinary rights, Fundamental
Rights can be changed only by amending
the Constitution.
2. Like Fundamental Rights, the ordinary
rights are guaranteed by the Constitution
of the country.
Which of the statement/s given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 Only
(b) 2 Only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Fundamental Rights can be changed only by amending the Constitution whereas the legislature is empowered to change ordinary laws by an ordinary process of law making.
Statement 2 is not correct: Unlike Fundamental Rights, the ordinary rights are not protected and guaranteed by the Constitution of the country. Fundamental Rights cannot be violated by any organ of the government.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements
1. Rule of law
2. Welfare state.
3. Freedom and dignity of the individual.
4. Sovereignty of Parliament.
How many of these are included in the “basic structure” of the Constitution through various Supreme Court judgements?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) Only Three
(d) All Four
batch.explanation:
In the Kesavananda Bharati case (1973), the Supreme Court laid down a new doctrine of the ‘basic structure’ of the Constitution. It ruled that the constituent power of Parliament under Article 368 does not enable it to alter the ‘basic structure’ of the Constitution. This means that the Parliament cannot abridge or take away a Fundamental Right that forms a part of the ‘basic structure’ of the Constitution.
However, the Supreme Court is yet to define or clarify as to what constitutes the ‘basic structure’ of the Constitution. From the various judgements, the following have emerged as ‘basic features’ of the Constitution or elements of the ‘basic structure’ of the constitution:
1) Supremacy of the Constitution
2) Sovereign, democratic and republican nature of the Indian polity
3) Secular character of the Constitution
4) Separation of powers between the legislature, the executive and the judiciary
5) Federal character of the Constitution
6) Unity and integrity of the nation
7) Welfare state (socio-economic justice)
8) Judicial review
9) Freedom and dignity of the individual
10)Parliamentary system
11) Rule of law
12) Harmony and balance between Fundamental Rights and Directive Principles
13) Principle of equality
14)Free and fair elections
15) Independence of Judiciary
16) Limited power of Parliament to amend the Constitution (not sovereignty of the Parliament)
17) Effective access to justice 18. Principles (or essence) underlying fundamental rights
18) Powers of the Supreme Court under Articles 32, 136, 141 and 142
19) Powers of the High Courts under Articles 226 and 227.
Therefore option c is the correct answer.                                                                                                           Sovereignty of Parliament is not part of basic structure of constitution.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Right to Freedom of Religion in the Constitution of India deals with which of the following provisions:
1. Freedom of conscience
2. Freedom to manage religious affairs
3. Freedom as to payment of taxes for promotion of any particular religion        
4. Freedom as to attendance at religious instruction in certain educational institutions.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 and 2 only
(b) 2, 3 and 4 only
(c) 1 only
(d) 1, 2, 3 and 4
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Article 25- Freedom of conscience and free profession, practice and propagation of religion.
Statement 2 is correct: Article 26- Freedom to manage religious affairs.
Statement 3 is correct: Article 27- Freedom as to payment of taxes for promotion of any particular religion.
Statement 4 is correct: Article 28- Freedom as to attendance at religious instruction or religious worship in certain educational institutions.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the Right to practise any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business, under the Constitution of India,consider the following statements:
1. Prescription of qualification for practicing any profession.
2. Baring companies from working with other listed companies.
3. Restriction on business in harmful drugs.
How many of the statements given above would amount to infringement of Freedom of Profession?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c)  All three
(d)  None of the above.
batch.explanation:
Article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution of India guarantees the Freedom of Profession, which gives citizens the freedom to practise any profession or to carry on any occupation, trade or business. The State can impose restrictions on the exercise of this Freedom on the grounds of public interest. Moreover, this Freedom does not include the freedom to carry on a profession or business that is immoral (trafficking of women or children) or dangerous (harmful drugs or explosives, etc.).
The Provision empowers the State to: 
• Prescribe necessary qualifications (professional or technical) for practising any profession or occupation, trade or business.
• Carry on any trade, business, industry or service.
Option 2 would be cosidered as an infringement.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance
batch.sub_topic: Right to Freedom of Profession- Aticle 19

batch.text:
The right to locomotion and travel abroad” is protected under which Article of Constitution of India:  
(a) Article 21
(b) Article 19
(c) Article 20
(d) Article 21A
batch.explanation:
The Freedom of Movement under Article 19 entitles every citizen to move freely throughout the territory of the country. The freedom of movement has two dimensions, viz, internal i.e. right to move inside the country and external i.e. right to move out of the country and right to come back to the country. Article 19 protects only the first dimension. The second dimension right to move out of the country and right to come back to the country is dealt by Article 21 (right to life and personal liberty). 
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
The right of Protection against arrest and detention in certain cases is guaranteed under which article?
(a) Article 21 
(b) Article 22 
(c) Article 23 
(d) Article 21 A
batch.explanation:
The second part of Article 22 grants protection to persons who are arrested or detained under a preventive detention law. This protection is available to both citizens as well as aliens and includes the following:
1. The detention of a person cannot exceed three months unless the advisory board reports sufficient cause for extended detention.The board is to consist of judges of a high court.
2. The grounds of detention should be communicated to the detenu. However, the facts considered to be against the public interest need not be disclosed. 
3. The detenu should be afforded an opportunity to make representation against the detention order.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements: 
1. Writ is a formal written judicial order issued to enforce fundamental rights only.
2. The Supreme Court can issue writ for the violation of both fundamental rights and legal rights.
3. The High Courts have been provided with more power on writ jurisdiction as compared to the Supreme Court.
How many of the above statements  is/are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c)  All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statements 1 and 2 are not correct: Writ is a formal written judicial order issued to enforce fundamental rights as well other rights like legal rights and statutory rights. 
The Supreme Court can issue writ for the violation of fundamental rights only. A High Court can issue a writ for violation of fundamental rights, statutory rights and legal rights. 
Statement 3 is correct: The High Courts have been provided with more power on writ jurisdiction as compared to the Supreme Court as law and order is a state subject and a High Court is the highest judicial organ of a state. 
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to Writs, consider the following statements:
1. Habeas Corpus is the only writ which can be issued against a private individual.
2. Prohibition can be issued against both a judicial body and an executive body.
3. Mandamus is issued by a court to enforce performance of a particular act by a lower court or a governmental officer or body, to correct a prior action or failure to act.
How many of these given statements  is/are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Habeas Corpus is issued against any form of illegal/arbitrary detention. It is issued against the state and individual. It is the only writ which can be issued against an individual.
Statement 2 is not correct: Prohibition can be issued against only a judicial body.
Statement 3 is correct: Mandamus writ is issued by a court to compel performance of a particular act by lower court or a governmental officer or body, to correct a prior action or failure to act. 
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Fundamental Rights, as provided in the Constitution of India, are
(a) Permanent and qualified.
(b) Guaranteed and available against the State only.
(c) Permanent and justiciable.
(d) Directly enforceable.
batch.explanation:
Fundamental Rights enshrined in the Constitution of India are specific to India and not universal in nature, they are available to citizens and foreigners within the boundaries of the country. They are qualified in nature, the Government can impose reasonable restrictions on Fundamental Rights available to citizens. Moreover, these rights are guaranteed by the Constitution and protected by the Supreme Court and are available mostly against the State but also against the private institutions and people also. All fundamental rights are not permanent, only the rights forming part of the basic structure of the Constitution are permanent; others can be changed or amended by amendment to the Constitution.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
An American citizen Mr. Donald is on tour to India, during the course of his stay, he is entitled to which of the following Fundamental Rights?
1. Freedom of practice and propagation of religion.
2. Equality before law.
3. Prohibition from discrimination in government job.
4. Freedom of speech and expression.
How many of these given statements  is/are correct?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) Only three
(d) All four
batch.explanation:
When in India, a foreigner is eligible for freedom of practice and propagation of religion and equality before law. The other two prohibitions from discrimination in government jobs and freedom of speech and expression are only available to Indian citizens.( Fundamental Rights under Article 15, 16, 19, 29 and 30 are available only to India citizens).
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right to freedom of speech and expression, consider the following:
1. Security of the State
2. Public order
3. Defamation
4. Contempt of Court
How many of the above is/are explicitly mentioned in the Constitution?
(a) All Four
(b) Only Three
(c) Only Two
(d) Only One
batch.explanation:
Article 19(2) provides for reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right to freedom of speech and expression in the interest of the sovereignty and integrity of India, the security of the State, friendly relations with foreign States, public order, decency or morality, or in relation to contempt of court, defamation or incitement to an offence. 
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
In essence, what does ‘Equal Protection of
Law’ mean?
(a) Equality of opportunity by law
(b) Equality of treatment by law
(c) Fair application of law
(d) Equality of law under equal circumstances.
batch.explanation:
The concept of “equal protection of laws (EPL)”
has been taken from the American Constitution.
It means that among equals the law should
be equal and equally administered. So, it is a
positive concept, implying the right to equality of
treatment in equal circumstances. 
Therefore option (d) is correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
How many of the following rights are available to both the citizens and foreigners.
1. Protection in respect of conviction for offences.
2. Right to elementary education.
3. Protection of culture of minorities.
4. Equality of opportunity in matters of Public employment.                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                            Select the correct answer using the code given
below:
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) Only three
(d) All four
batch.explanation:
Fundamental rights available to both the citizens and foreigners: Protection in respect of conviction for offences, Right to elementary education.                                                                                                                                                                        Fundamental rights available only to citizens are : Protection of culture of minorities , Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment. Hence only statement 1 and 2 are correct.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to Fundamental Rights, consider the following statements:
1. Article 14 states that the State shall notdeny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India.
2. Article 15 states that there should not be any discrimination on the basis of caste, race and religion only.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Article 14 states that the State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India. Article 14 of the Indian Constitution guarantees equality before the law to all persons, regardless of their race, religion, caste, sex, or place of birth. 
Statement 2 is incorrect: According to Article 15, The State shall not discriminate against any citizen on grounds only of religion, race, caste, sex, place of birth or any of them. Hence, sex and place of birth are also grounds on which the state can’t discriminate.
Therefore, option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. State shall not recognise any specific
religion as their official religion.
2. State observes neutrality and impartiality
towards all religion.
3. State maintains a strict separation from
religion in matters of governance
How many of these provisions correctly
explains the nature of Indian Secularism?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct:In India, the state shall not recognise any specific religion as their official religion. 
Statement 2 is correct.:The state can’t favor or discriminate against any religion and it equally appreciates all the religions.
Statement 3 is incorrect:In India, both state and religion can, and often do, interact with each other within the legally prescribed and judicially settled parameters.
Hence, only two of the given statements correctly explains the nature of Indian Secularism.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following rights:
1. Equality before law.
2. Equality of opportunity in the matters of
public employment.
3. Abolition of Untouchability.
4. Abolition of titles.
How many of the rights given above are not the Fundamental Rights under Right to Equality?
(a) Only two
(b) Only three
(c) All four
(d) None of the above
batch.explanation:
• The articles 14 to 18 of the Indian constitution constitute the Fundamental Right to Equality.
• Equality before law comes under Article 14
• Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment comes under Article 16 
• Abolition of Untouchability is under Article 17. 
• Abolition of titles is covered under Article 18. Hence all rights given above are the Fundamental Rights under Right to Equality. 
Therefore option (d) is correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the Equality of Opportunity in the constitution of India,consider the following statement:
1. It provides for equality of opportunity for
all in public and private employment.
2. It prohibits discrimination only on the
grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, place
of birth, residence or any of them.
3. It empowers the President to provide by
law, residence as a ground of qualification
in certain employment under the state.
How many of the statements given above is/are
correct?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect:Article 16 of the Indian constitution deals with Equality of opportunity in matters of employment. It provides for equality of opportunity for all in offices under the state only i.e public employment. There are no provisions for private employment. 
Statement 2 is incorrect:It prohibits discrimination only on the grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, descent, place of birth,residence or any of them. So descent is also a ground. 
Statement 3 is incorrect.:It empowers the Parliament to provide by law residence as a ground of qualification in certain employment under the state. 
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements with reference to the Fundamental Rights and Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP):
1. Fundamental Rights imposes restrictions on the State while DPSP are Positive In nature.
2. Fundamental Rights are Individual rights however DPSP are collective Rights. 
3. Violation of Fundamental Rights can attract Judicial Intervention, which is not always the case with DPSP. 
How many of the statements given above is/are correct?
a) Only One
b) Only Two
c) All Three
d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Articles 12-35 of Indian Constitution deal with Fundamental Rights. These rights are conferred upon the citizens of India for the Constitution tells that these rights are inviolable. Right to Life, Right to Dignity, and Right to Education etc. all come under one of the six main fundamental rights. These are negative as they prohibit the State from doing certain things and articles 36-51 under Part-IV of the Indian Constitution deal with Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP). They are borrowed from the Constitution of Ireland. These are positive as they require the State to do certain things.
Statement 2 is correct: Fundamental rights promote the welfare of the individual. Hence, they are personal and individualistic. And directive principles of state policy promote the welfare of the community. Hence, they are societarian and socialistic.
Statement 3 is correct: Fundamental rights have legal sanctions hence they do not require any legislation for their implementation. They are automatically enforced and directive principles have moral and Political sanctions. They require legislation for their implementation. They are not automatically enforced.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Under the Constitution, “to renounce practices derogatory to the dignity of women;” is a
(a) Fundamental Duty
(b) Directive Principles of State Policy
(c) Fundamental Right
(d) Statutory Duty
batch.explanation:
"to promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood amongst all the people of India transcending religious, linguistic and regional or sectional diversities; to renounce practices derogatory to the dignity of women" is a Fundamental Duty under Article 51A.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the Part IV-A of Constitution of India, consider the following provisions are 
1. To defend the country and render national service
2. To value and preserve the rich heritage of our composite culture
3. To safeguard public property and to abjure violence
How many of the provision/s given above is/are not mentioned in Part IVA?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None of the above
batch.explanation:
Some of the provisions under Article 51A are:
It shall be the duty of every citizen of India—
1. to defend the country and render national service when called upon to do so
2. to value and preserve the rich heritage of our composite culture
3. to safeguard public property and to abjure violence
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to Part IVA of Indian Constitution, which of the following statement is not correct?
(a) It contains only one article.
(b) It was instituted by 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976
(c) It has never been amended since its incorporation in constitution.
(d) This feature has been inspired from the constitution of erstwhile USSR.
batch.explanation:
Option (a) is correct: Part IV A has only 1 article 51A under it all the 11 fundamental duties are mentioned.
Option (b) is correct: The 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976 added this part in Indian Constitution.
Option (c) is not correct: The Eighty-sixth Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002 added a new fundamental duty “who is a parent or guardian to provide opportunities for education to his child or, as the case may be, ward between the age of six and fourteen years”.
Option (d) is correct: The fundamental duties in Indian Constitution are inspired from the constitution of erstwhile USSR.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
For an Indian citizen, To value and preserve the rich heritage of our composite culture is mentioned in which of the following ?
1. Fundamental Duty
2. Directive Principle of State Policy
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
The Article 51A of our constitution which contains fundamental duties states in clause “f” that “It shall be the duty of every citizen of India to value and preserve the rich heritage of our composite culture.”
Therefore option (a) is correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With respect to the Article 1 of the Indian Constitution consider the following provisions: 
1. Establishment of New States
2. Name of  the Country 
3. Definition of State
4. Type of Polity 
How many of the following provisions are reflected under ‘Article 1’ of the Indian Constitution?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three 
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statements 2 and 4 are correct: Article 1 describes India, that is, Bharat as a ‘Union of States’ rather than a ‘Federation of States’. This provision deals with two things: one, name of the country; and two, type of polity.
1) Name of Country: There was no unanimity in the Constituent Assembly with regard to the name of the country. Some members suggested the traditional name (Bharat), while others advocated the modern name (India). Hence, the Constituent Assembly had to adopt a mix of both (‘India, that is, Bharat’). 
2) Type of Polity: India is described as ‘Union’ although its Constitution is federal in structure. According to Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, the phrase ‘Union of States’ has been preferred to ‘Federation of States’. The federation is a Union because it is indestructible. The country is an integral whole and divided into different states only for the convenience of administration. Statement 1 and 3 are incorrect: Article 2 deals with the provisions regarding establishment of new states. It empowers the Parliament to ‘admit into the Union of India, or establish, new states on such terms and conditions as it thinks fit’. Article 12 describes the definition of State; including the Government and Parliament of India and the Government and the Legislature of each of the States and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.
Therefore option (b) is correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to Advisory Jurisdiction of Supreme Court, which of the following statements is/are correct:
a) The Supreme Court must tender its opinion to the President if the dispute arises out of any pre-constitution treaty.
b) The advice tendered by the Supreme Court with regards to the pre constitutional treaty is binding on the President.
Select the correct answer using the code given below.
(a) 1 only 
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: The Constitution (Article 143) authorises the president to seek the opinion of the Supreme Court in the two categories of matters:
(a) On any question of law or fact of public importance which has arisen or which is likely to arise.
(b) On any dispute arising out of any pre-constitution treaty, agreement, covenant, engagement, sanad or other
similar instruments.
Statement 2 is incorrect: The advice tendered by the Supreme Court with regards to the pre constitutional treaty is not binding on the President. The opinion expressed by the Supreme Court is only advisory and not a judicial pronouncement. Hence, it is not binding on the president; he may follow or may not follow the opinion.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
The power to increase the number of judges in the Supreme Court of India is vested in:
(a) the Law ministry
(b) the Parliament
(c) the Chief Justice of India
(d) the Law Commission
batch.explanation:
The power to increase the number of judges in the Supreme Court of India is vested in the parliament. At present, The Supreme Court consists of thirty-four judges (one chief justice and thirty-three other judges). In 2019, the centre notified an increase in the number of Supreme Court judges from thirty-one to thirty-four, including the
Chief Justice of India. This followed the enactment of the Supreme Court (Number of Judges) Amendment Act,2019. Originally, the strength of the Supreme Court was fixed at eight (one chief justice and seven other judges).
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
“The Supreme Court shall be a court of record and shall have all the powers of such a court including the power to punish for contempt of itself.”
The above given provision is mentioned in which article?
(a) Article 127
(b) Article 128
(c) Article 129
(d) Article 130
batch.explanation:
Article 129 provides for Supreme Court to be a court of record. It reads, The Supreme Court shall be a court of record and shall have all the powers of such a court including the power to punish for contempt of itself.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Which one of the following categories of disputes is excluded from the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of India 
(a) Between the Government of India and one or more states.
(b) Between two or more states.
(c) Between residents of two or more states.
(d) Between the Government of India and one or more states on one side and one or more other states on the other.
batch.explanation:
Article 131 speaks of the original jurisdiction. Original jurisdiction means the power to hear and determine a dispute in the first instance. The Supreme Court has been given exclusive original jurisdiction which extends to disputes
(a) between the Government of India and one or more States,
(b) between the Government of India and one or more States on one side and one or more States on the other,
(c) between two or more States. 
However, this jurisdiction shall not extend to a dispute arising out of treaty, agreement, etc. which is in operation and excludes such jurisdiction.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Which of the following articles of the Indian Constitution deals with the Establishment and constitution of the Supreme Court?
(a) Article 123
(b) Article 124
(c) Article 125
(d) Article 126
batch.explanation:
Article 124 deals with Establishment and constitution of Supreme Court. It reads: There shall be a Supreme Court of India consisting of a Chief Justice of India and, until Parliament by law prescribes a larger number, of not more than [seven] other Judges.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements: 
1. The Constitution declares Delhi as the seat of the Supreme Court. 
2. The President can appoint other seats of the Supreme Court. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
 (a) 1 only
 (b) 2 only 
(c) Both 1 and 2 
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: The constitution of India declares Delhi as the seat of the Supreme Court.
Statement 2 is not correct: The Chief Justice of India is authorised by the Constitution to appoint another place or places as seat of the Supreme court. He can take any such decision only with the prior recommendation of the President.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. In India, a Constitution Amendment Act is immune from judicial review for infringement of the Fundamental Rights.
2. The Parliament can amend any provisions of the Constitution of India.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: A Constitution Amendment Act is not immune from judicial review for infringement of Fundamental Rights.                                                                                                                                                                 Statement 2 is  correct:The Parliament under Article 368 can amend any part of the Constitution including the Fundamental Rights but without affecting the 'basic structure' of the Constitution.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1.  Parliament can extend, but cannot curtail the jurisdiction and power of the Supreme Court.
2.  A retired judge of the Supreme Court cannot appear or plead in any court or before any authority within the territory of India.
3.  The salaries and allowances of the judges of the Supreme Court are charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.
Which of these statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 and 2
(b)  2 and 3
(c)  1 and 3 
(d)  1, 2 and 3
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Parliament can't curtail the jurisdiction but expand it only.
Statement 2 is correct: A person who has been a Judge of the Supreme Court is debarred from practising in any court of law or before any other authority in India.
Statement 3 is correct: The Salaries, Pension and Allowances of the Supreme Court Judges are charged upon the Consolidated Fund of India, whereas the Salaries and Allowances of the High Court Judges are charged upon the Consolidated Fund of the States and the Pension is charged on the Consolidated Fund of India.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance
batch.sub_topic: Supreme Court- Judges salary n Jurisdicition

batch.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the Supreme Court of India are correct?
1. It has the power to entertain appeals from any court or tribunal within India.
2. It has the power to deliver advisory opinion on any question of fact or law referred to it by the President.
3. Salaries of the Judges of the Supreme Court are subject to vote by the Parliament.
4. Its jurisdiction is binding on all other courts within India.
Select the correct answer from the code given below:
(a)  1 and 3 
(b)  2 and 4
(c)  2, 3 and 4 
(d)  1, 2 and 4
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: The Supreme Court has the power to entertain appeals from any court or tribunal within India.The Supreme Court is authorised to grant in its discretion special leave to appeal from any judgement in any matter passed by any court or tribunal in the country except military tribunal and court martial
Statement 2 is correct: The Jurisdiction of the Supreme Court of India can broadly be categorised into three parts:
1. Original Jurisdiction
2. Appellate Jurisdiction
3. Advisory Jurisdiction
Article 143 of the Constitution of India confers upon the Supreme Court advisory jurisdiction.
Statement 3 is not correct:The salaries of judges cannot be reduced except during the period of financial emergency. Their salaries and allowances are charged to the Consolidated Fund of India and so are not subject to vote of Parliament.
Statement 4 is correct:The verdict/ jurisdiction is binding on all the courts within India.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Which of the following Constitutional Amendment Acts included Part XIV-A (entitled as ‘Tribunals’) in the Constitution of India?
(a)  42nd Amendment Act 
(b)  44th Amendment Act
(c)  47th Amendment Act
(d)  49th Amendment Act"
batch.explanation:
Tribunals were added in the Constitution by Constitution (Forty-second Amendment) Act, 1976 as Part XIV-A, which has only two articles viz. 323-A and 323-B. While article 323-A deals with Administrative Tribunals; article 323-B deals with tribunals for other matters.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the removal of judges of
the Supreme Court, consider the following
statements:
1. He/She can be removed by order of the
President.
2. Judges Enquiry Act, 1968 regulates the
procedure relating to the removal of a judge
3. No judge has been impeached so far in
India.
How many of the statement/s given above is/are
correct?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: A judge of Supreme court can be removed by order of the President.
President can issue a removal order only after an address by the Parliament has been presented to him for such removal. The address must be supported by a special majority of each House of Parliament.
Statement 2 is correct: The procedure for the removal of judges is elaborated in the Judges Inquiry Act, 1968.
Statement 3 is correct: No judge has been impeached so far in India.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to advisory jurisdiction of
the Supreme Court, consider the following
statements:
1. Article 142 gives powers to the President
of India to consult the Supreme court on
certain matters.
2. If at any time it appears to the President
that a question of law or fact has arisen, he/
she may refer the question to the Supreme
Court for consideration.
3. The opinion expressed by the Supreme
court is binding on the President.
How many of the statement/s given above is/are
correct?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: Article 143 gives powers to the President of India to consult the Supreme court on certain matters.
Statement 2 is correct: If at any time it appears to the President that a question of law or fact has arisen, or is likely to arise, which is of such a nature and of such public importance that it is expedient to obtain the opinion of the Supreme Court upon it, he may refer the question to the Court for consideration.
Statement 3 is not correct: The opinion expressed by the Supreme court is not binding on the President.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, consider the following disputes
1. Dispute between the Government of India
and one or more States
2. Dispute between two or more States
3. Dispute arising out of any treaty having
been entered before the commencement of
Constitution
How many of the dispute/s given above is/are
correct?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 and 2 are correct:According to Article 131, the Supreme Court have original jurisdiction in dispute—
(a) between the Government of India and one or more States; or
(b) between the Government of India and any State or States on one side and one or more other States on the other; or
(c) between two or more States.                                                                                                                                            Statement 3 is not correct:However, it shall not extend to a dispute arising out of any treaty, agreement or other similar instrument which, having been entered into or executed before the commencement of this Constitution. Hence, 
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Form of oath or affirmation to be made by the Judges of the Supreme Court is mentioned in
(a) Second Schedule
(b) Third Schedule
(c) Fourth Schedule
(d) Fifth Schedule
batch.explanation:
Form of oath or affirmation to be made by the Judges of the Supreme Court is mentioned in Third Schedule.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the Judges of High court,Consider the following statements:
1. The Constitution of India has fixed a six year tenure of a judge of a high court
2. He/She can resign his office by writing to the Governor.
3. He/She vacates his office when he is appointed as a judge of the Supreme Court or when he is transferred to another high court.
How many of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: The Constitution has not fixed the tenure of a judge of a high court.
Statement 2 is not correct: He/She can resign his/her office by writing to the president.
Statement 3 is correct: He/She vacates his office when he is appointed as a judge of the Supreme Court or when he is transferred to another high court.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
"With regard to qualifications needed to become a judge of High court, which of the following statements is/are correct?
1. He should have a minimum 10 years of practice as an advocate of the High court.
2. He should be an eminent jurist in the opinion of the President of India.
3. He should have been a judge in district Court for at least 10 years.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
a) 1 only
b) 1 and 2 only
c) 2 and 3 only
d) 1 and 3 only"
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: In order to become judge of High court, a person should have minimum 10 years of practice as an advocate of High court or High courts in succession for 10 years. He should be a citizen of India also.
Statement 2 is incorrect: The constitution makes no provision for appointment of a distinguished jurist as a judge of the High court. But a distinguished jurist can become a judge of the Supreme court.
Statement 3 is correct: He should have held a judicial office in the territory of India for 10 years. That means he should have been a judge in any of the state Subordinate Court for at least 10 years.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
How can the number of Judges in the Supreme Court of India be increased?
(a)  By a Presidential notification
(b)  By a Parliamentary Act
(c)  By an Amendment of the Constitution of India
(d)  By a Representation from the Supreme Court
batch.explanation:
The Parliament of India has authority to make laws, organise jurisdiction and modify the powers of the Supreme Court. The number of judges in the Supreme Court can be increased or decreased by the parliament by legislation.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following acts about the Indian parliament
1. Admit a new state in the Union of India.
2. Alter the boundaries of any state.
3. Bifurcate a state.
How many of the above acts Indian parliament can do  under Article 3 of the Indian constitution ?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Under Article 3 Parliament can-
(a) Form a new state by separation of territory from any state by uniting two or more states or parts of state or by uniting any territory to a part of any state.
(b) Increase the area of any state.
(c) Diminish the area of any state.
(d) Alter the boundaries of any state.
(e) Alter the name of any state.
Under Article 2 Parliament can admit into the union or establish new states on such terms and conditions and it thinks fit.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. “Territory of India” includes only States.
2. “Union of India” includes both states and Union territories.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 and 2 is not correct:The expression ‘Union of India’ is distinct from the expression ‘territory of India’. The territory of India includes the states, the union territory and the acquired territory. The Union of India includes only states.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance
batch.sub_topic: Territory of India and Union of India

batch.text:
Which of the following statements is/are correct regarding the bills introduced under Article 3 of the constitution?
1. It can be introduced in the Parliament only with the prior recommendation of the President.
2. Before introduction in the Parliament, the President has to refer it to the concerned state legislature or to the Union Territory for expressing its views within a specified period.
3. The Bill is considered as an amendment under Article 368 of the constitution.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: The first condition is, a bill contemplating the above changes can be introduced in the Parliament only with the prior recommendation of the President.
Statement 2 is not correct: The second condition is, before recommending the bill to the Parliament, the President has to refer the same to the state legislature concerned for expressing its views within a specified period. But, in the case of a union territory, no reference needs to be made to the concerned legislature to ascertain its views and the Parliament can itself take any action as it deems fit.
Statement 3 is not correct: The Constitution (Article 4) itself declares that laws made for admission or establishment of new states (under Article 2) and formation of new states and alteration of areas, boundaries or names of existing states (under Articles 3) are not to be considered as amendments of the Constitution under Article 368.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the powers of the Parliament, consider the following statements:
1. Power of Parliament to diminish the area of a state under Article 3 does not cover cession of Indian Territory to a foreign country.
2. Settlement of a boundary dispute between India and another country does not require a Constitutional Amendment.
3. Altering boundaries of a state can only be done via a Constitutional Amendment under Article 368.
How many of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: The Supreme Court held in the Berubari Union case that the power of Parliament to
diminish the area of a state (under Article 3) does not cover cession of Indian territory to a foreign country.
Hence, Indian territory can be ceded to a foreign state only by amending the Constitution under Article 368.
Statement 2 is correct: The Supreme Court in 1969 ruled that, settlement of a boundary dispute between India
and another country does not require a constitutional amendment. It can be done by executive action as it does
not involve cession of Indian territory to a foreign country.
Statement 3 is incorrect: As per Article 4 of the constitution altering boundaries of a state does not require a
constitutional amendment under Article 368 and can be done via a simple majority in the parliament.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the Gram Nyayalaya How many of the above statements is/are correct?
1. It is a statutory body formed by the Legal Services Authorities Act, 1987.
2. They cannot hear criminal cases.
3. The Act allows local social activists as mediators.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 and 3 only
(b) 2 only
(c) 3 only
(d) 1, 2 and 3
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: The Gram Nyayalayas Act, 2008 establishes Gram Nyayalayas aimed at providing inexpensive justice to people in rural areas at their doorsteps. Gram Nyayalayas are to be established for every Panchayat at intermediate level or a group of contiguous Panchayats at intermediate level or for a group of contiguous Gram Panchayats.
Statement 2 is not correct: The Gram Nyayalayas can try criminal cases, civil suits, claims or disputes which are specified in the First Schedule and the Second Schedule to the Gram Nyayalayas Act. They shall also settle civil suits dealing with land, water, etc., as listed in a Schedule. In civil disputes, Gram Nyayalayas shall not be bound by the procedure in Code of Civil Procedure, 1908, or the rules of evidence in the Indian Evidence Act, 1872. In criminal cases, the court shall follow procedures for summary trials. Appeals in civil and criminal cases shall be heard by the senior civil judge and the assistant sessions judge, respectively. Further appeals are not permitted.
Statement 3 is correct: The Act also makes the judicial process participatory and decentralised because it allows appointment of local social activists and lawyers as mediators. The Gram Nyayalayas are guided by the principles of natural justice subject to any rule made by the High Court.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements regarding the
appointment of judges to the High Court:
1. The judges are appointed by Governor
through a group of judges called the
collegium.
2. A distinguished jurist is eligible to become
a judge of the High Court
3. Constitution of India has prescribed
a minimum age of fifty years for the
appointment as a judge of the High Court.
How many of the statement/s given above is/are
correct?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: The judges of High Courts are appointed by President
Statement 2 is not correct: A distinguished jurist is eligible to become a judge of the Supreme Court (not the High Court) with the final approval of the President.
Statement 3 is not correct: Constitution of India has not prescribed a minimum age for the appointment as a judge of High Court.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Who among the following is authorized to
establish a common High Court for two or
more States as well as to constitute a High
Court even for a Union Territory?
(a) President
(b) Chief Justice of India
(c) Parliament
(d) Parliament after recommendation from
the Chief Justice of India
batch.explanation:
The Parliament is empowered to prescribe the number of Judges of the Supreme Court by law. It is also authorized to establish a common High Court for two or more States as well as to constitute a High Court even for a Union Territory.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With respect to the various parts of the constitution of India, consider the following pairs
Part.         Subject
1. Part I    Citizenship
2. Part II   The union and its territory
3. Part III  Fundamental Rights
How many of the pair/s given above is/are not correctly matched?
(a) Only one pair
(b) Only two pairs
(c) All three pairs
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Pair 1 is not correct: Part I is the union and its
territory.
Pair 2 is not correct: Part II is citizenship.
Pair 3 is correct: Part III is fundamental rights.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following provisions
1. Formation of new states
2. Alteration of boundaries of existing states
3. Abolition or creation of legislative councils in states.
How many of the provision/s given above can be amended by a simple majority of Parliament?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
A number of provisions in the Constitution can be amended by simple majority of the two Houses of Parliament outside the scope of Article 368. Some of these are:
1. Formation of new states and alteration of areas, boundaries or names of existing states [Article 3].
2. Abolition or creation of legislative councils in states [Article 169].
Therefore, All three provisions given above can be amended by a simple majority of Parliament.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following territories
1. Territories of the states
2. Union territories
3. Such territories which may be acquired by the Government of India at any time.
How many of the territories given above are included in the expression ‘Union of States’ under Article 1 of the Indian Constitution?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
As per the Article 1 of our constitution, ‘Union of States’ consist of the territories of the States while ‘Territory of India’ comprises of 
(a) the territories of the States; 
(b) the Union territories and 
(c) such other territories which may be acquired by the Government of India Hence, Only One of the territories given above are included in the expression ‘Union of States’ under Article 1.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the loss of citizenship in India, Consider the following
1. The citizen has obtained citizenship by fraud
2. The citizen voluntarily acquires the citizenship of another country
3. The citizen has shown disloyalty to the Constitution of India.
How many of the above acts can result in the loss of citizenship in India?
(a) Only one
(b) Only two
(c) All three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
The Citizenship Act (1955) prescribes the ways of losing citizenship in India:
• When an Indian citizen voluntarily acquires the citizenship of another country, his Indian citizenship automatically terminates.
• The central Government can also terminate the citizenship if the citizen has obtained the citizenship by fraud, the citizen has shown disloyalty to the Constitution of India, the citizen has unlawfully traded or communicated with the enemy during a war etc.
Hence, All three of the above acts can result in the loss of citizenship in India.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Arrange the following states in the order of their formation, from earliest to the latest
1. Gujarat
2. Haryana
3. Manipur
4. Nagaland
Select the correct answer using the code given below
(a) 1-3-4-2 
(b) 1-4-2-3 
(c) 4-1-2-3
(d) 4-3-1-2
batch.explanation:
• Gujarat was established as the 15th state of the Indian Union in 1960.
• Nagaland was established as the 16th state of the Indian Union in 1963.
• Haryana was established as the 17th state of the Indian Union in 1966.
• Manipur was established as the 19th state of Indian Union in 1972.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. The President can increase or decrease a scheduled area.
2. The Governor of a state can increase or decrease the area of an autonomous district.
Which of the statements given above is/are not correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: The President can increase or decrease the area of a scheduled area.
Statement 2 is correct: The governor of a state can increase or decrease the areas and autonomous districts.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance
batch.sub_topic: President of India / Governor of State

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. Election for the next President shall be completed before the expiration of the term of incumbent President. 
2. If the term of the President’s office expires and no elections have been held for the next President, then the Vice-President takes charge as the President.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: An election to fill a vacancy caused by the expiration of the term of office of President shall be completed before the expiration of the term.
Statement 2 is not correct: If the election for the next President gets delayed, the President can hold office beyond his term of 5 years until the successor assumes charge.
However, if the office falls vacant by resignation, removal, and death or otherwise, then the elections to fill the vacancy should be held within six months from the date of the occurrence of such a vacancy. In such cases, till the time a new President is elected, the Vice-President acts as the President.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Which among the following constitutional posts, the person holds office during the pleasure of the President of India?
1. Prime Minister
2. Chief Election Commissioner
3. Attorney General of India
4. Comptroller and Auditor General of India.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) All Four
(b) Only Three
(c) Only Two
(d) Only One
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: The term of the Prime Minister is not fixed and he holds office during the pleasure of the president. However, this does not mean that the president can dismiss the Prime Minister at any time. So long as the Prime Minister enjoys the majority support in the Lok Sabha, he cannot be dismissed by the President. However, if he loses the confidence of the Lok Sabha, he must resign or the President can dismiss him.
Statement 2 is incorrect: The Election Commission shall consist of the chief election commissioner and such number of other election commissioners, if any, as the president may from time to time fix. Any other election commissioner or a regional commissioner cannot be removed from office except on the recommendation of the chief election commissioner. The chief election commissioner is provided with the security of tenure. He cannot be removed from his office except in the same manner and on the same grounds as a judge of the Supreme Court. Thus, he does not hold his office till the pleasure of the president, though he is appointed by him.
Statement 3 is correct: The Attorney General (AG) is appointed by the president. He must be a person who is qualified to be appointed a judge of the Supreme Court. The term of office of the AG is not fixed by the Constitution. Further, the Constitution does not contain the procedure and grounds for his removal. He holds office during the pleasure of the president. This means that he may be removed by the president at any time. He may also quit his office by submitting his resignation to the president. Conventionally, he resigns when the government (council of ministers) resigns or is replaced, as he is appointed on its advice.
Statement 4 is incorrect: The CAG is appointed by the president of India by a warrant under his hand and seal.He holds office for a period of six years or up to the age of 65 years, whichever is earlier. He can resign anytime from his office by addressing the resignation letter to the president. He can also be removed by the president on the same grounds and in the same manner as a judge of the Supreme Court. Thus, he does not hold his office till the pleasure of the president, though he is appointed by him.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to veto powers of the President of India, consider the following statements: 
1. The President can reject all types of bills presented before him for his assent.
2. The President cannot return a money bill for reconsideration.
3. When the President keeps a bill pending with himself for an indefinite period, it is termed as Suspensive Veto.
How many of the above statements are correct?
(a) Only One
(b) Only Two
(c) All Three
(d) None
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: The President can reject all types of bills except for the Constitutional Amendment Bill, presented before him for his/her assent.
Statement 2 is correct: The President cannot return a money bill for reconsideration. Normally, the President gives his assent to a money bill as it is introduced in the Parliament with his previous permission.
Statement 3 is not correct: When the President keeps a bill pending for an indefinite period, it is termed as Pocket Veto. Other types of veto enjoyed by the President are Absolute Veto and Suspensive Veto.
Therefore, option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Tribal areas in which of the following states have been constituted into Autonomous districts?
1. Tripura
2. Arunachal Pradesh
3. Nagaland
4. Mizoram
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
(a) 1 and 3 only
(b) 2, 3 and 4 only
(c) 1 and 4 only
(d) 1, 2, 3 and 4
batch.explanation:
Governors of four states viz. Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura and Mizoram are empowered to declare some tribal dominated districts/areas of these states as autonomous districts and autonomous regions by order.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the pardoning power of the President, Which of the following is/are correct?
(a) Any decision by the President on a pardon request must carry an explanation.
(b) The petitioner must be given an oral hearing before deciding upon their pardon requests.
(c) The President has exclusive pardoning power with respect to punishments by Military courts.
(d) None of the above
batch.explanation:
Option (a) is not correct:The President is not bound to give reasons for his order.
Option (b) is not correct: The petitioner has no right to an oral hearing by the President.
Option (c) is correct: The President has exclusive pardoning power with respect to punishments by Military courts.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
The president can nominate members to the Rajya Sabha from people with special knowledge or practical experience in
(a) art, literature, science and social service.
(b) social service, co-operative societies and literature.
(c) literature, rural development and co-operative societies.
(d) science, art, literature and co-operative societies.
batch.explanation:
The President nominates 12 members to the Rajya Sabha from people who have special knowledge or practical experience in art, literature, science and social service. The rationale behind this principle of nomination is to provide eminent persons a place in the Rajya Sabha without going through the process of election.
Therefore option (a) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. The President of India can promulgate ordinances for subjects mentioned in Union and Concurrent lists only.
2. The Governor of a state can promulgate ordinances for subjects mentioned in State and Concurrent lists only.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a)  1 only
(b) 2 only
(c)  Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: The President of India can promulgate ordinances for subjects mentioned in Union and Concurrent lists.The President can also promulgate an ordinance on State list when the Parliament is not in session during national emergency.
Statement 2 is correct: The Governor of a state can promulgate ordinances for subjects mentioned in State and Concurrent lists only.
Therefore option (b) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Which of the following would be used by the President to terminate a session of parliament?
(a)  Adjournment
(b)  Dissolution
(c)  Prorogation
(d)  Adjournment sine die
batch.explanation:
An adjournment terminates the sitting of the House. A house can be adjourned by the presiding officers of the respective houses and the house can meet again at the time appointed for the next sitting. An adjournment also signifies a brief break during the sitting of the House and it can reassemble at an appointed time on the same day.
Dissolution of the House means the end of the life of the Lok Sabha either by an order made by the President under Article 85 (2)(b) of the Constitution or on the expiration of the period of five years from the date appointed for its first meeting.
Prorogation is the termination of a session of Parliament by an order made by the President under Article 85(2)(a) of the Constitution.
Adjournment sine die is the termination of a sitting of the House without any definite date being fixed for the next sitting.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the President of India, which of the following statements is/are correct?
1. The President is an integral part of the Parliament.
2. The President shall not be a member of either House of Parliament.
Select the correct answer using the code given below: 
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: Parliament of India consists of the President, and the two Houses — Council of States (Rajya Sabha) and the House of the People (Lok Sabha). Though the President is an integral part of the Parliament, he shall not be a member of either House. There are certain constitutional functions which he has to perform with respect to Parliament. E.g. The President has the power to summon and prorogue either House of Parliament or to dissolve Lok Sabha. 
Statement 2 is correct: President shall not be a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State. And if a member of either House of Parliament or of a House of the Legislature of any State is elected as President, he shall be deemed to have vacated his seat in that House on the date on which he enters upon his office as President.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
With reference to the President of India, consider the following statements: 
1. The international treaties and agreements are negotiated and concluded on behalf of the President. 
2. The President can declare war or conclude peace, subject to ratification by the Parliament. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct? 
(a) 1 only 
(b) 2 only 
(c)  Both 1 and 2 
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct: The international treaties and agreements are negotiated and concluded on behalf of the President.
Statement 2 is correct: The President can also declare war or conclude peace, subject to ratification by the Parliament.
Therefore option (c) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance
batch.sub_topic: President of India-- Diplomatic Powers/Military Powers

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1 The President of India has been provided with both constitutional and situational discretionary powers. 
2.The Governors in a state have only situational discretionary power. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: The President of India has been provided only with situational discretionary power. 
Statement 2 is not correctGovernors of any state have both constitutional and situational discretionary powers. The Governor can use his discretionary power for recommending the President's rule in a state, reserve a bill for the President etc. 
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance
batch.sub_topic: President of India-Governor of the State-- Powers

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. A member of the Council of Ministers must be a member of any house of the Parliament.
2. Prime Minister in India should be a member of the Lower House of the Parliament.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct: A member of the Council of Ministers has to be a member of any house of the Parliament. However, even if a person is not a member of any of the two Houses, he can become a Minister for a period of six months.
Statement 2 is not correct: The Prime Minister in India can be a member of any house of the Parliament. Indira Gandhi and Manmohan Singh were members of Rajya Sabha during their terms of office as Prime Minister of India. In England, a Prime Minister should be a member of the Lower House of the Parliament.
Therefore option (d) is the correct answer.
batch.subject: Polity and Governance

batch.text:
Consider the following statements:
1. Executive Power of the Union of India is vested in the Prime Minister.
2. All executive actions of the Government of India shall be expressed to be taken in the name of the Prime Minister. 
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
(a) 1 only
(b) 2 only
(c) Both 1 and 2
(d) Neither 1 nor 2
batch.explanation:
